output: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year, the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue is celebrated.
The involvement of all and the perception that education, knowledge, and the intertwining of different cultures with each other is crucial is already a fact given as acquired.
Therefore, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its role, and in this new perspective, a new document is already present.

The Erasmus Mundus program is an important contribution to the creation of excellence centers in the EU, which will in a way sustain the brain drain from the European Union, as it represents a significant role.

The promotion of European values together with the national values of third countries that come to study here and find in the old continent a cultural and linguistic diversity that is unmatched and that functions as an attractive pole and distinct from existing models in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have been quite enough to survive.

The problem of visas for Erasmus students in the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them leads to a situation of semi-clandestinity in the European Union, as they attend master's programs, but with tourist visas and sometimes expired.
I consider of the greatest relevance and urgency the search for a solution that allows speed and transparency and efficiency in the issuance of visas for these students.
Also, the knowledge of the language that allows cultural perception and mutual coexistence, beyond the strictly academic domain, is crucial, so that we can guarantee this premise absolutely.
To conclude, I would like to express my gratitude to Deputy De Sarnes for the way in which she conducted this entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. The authorization for the concession of state aid for the modernization and renovation of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should be possible only until the end of 2009 or should be valid for an indefinite period.
The peculiarities of fishing activity in these regions justify that these aids can be granted beyond two thousand and nine, without the marine environment being minimally affected.
State aid for the modernization and renewal of the fleets of the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
Would be immediately interrupted if the studies and the assessment of the scientific council and the regional advisory councils were to show this need.
This solution that would best suit the very specific reality of the fisheries of the outermost regions.

The same reasons that justify for fishermen of each a fishing reserve up to one hundred miles also justify a differentiated treatment regarding the aids for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, at the Commission for Fisheries, the best solutions were found that can meet the particularities of fisheries in the region, in the outermost regions.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup. I would like to greet not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for having initiated this text, the ten-year review of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as was said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has shown resilience and solidity even during the serious turbulence we are witnessing. It is clear that the borders of this club should be expanded.
But the times that are running put the solidity of the European project to the test on many other dimensions.
The euro, as I said, is a central instrument of the functioning of the financial system.

However, the text of the Commission itself clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor the convergence in social or spatial terms has accompanied this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have worsened violently during the decade of the single currency's operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country, in particular, in particular the north of Portugal, but also other regions of member countries.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, especially due to the very high exchange rate applied, will affect more the regions that are more exposed to international competition and the more export-oriented regions.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets violently affects the real economy and further aggravates the situation of many citizens and regions.

These regions, those that are exposed to international competition, those that depend on small and medium-sized enterprises, those in which access to credit is most important, are today victims of this process and are even threatened by depression.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the trust that European citizens place in it.
The most powerful European countries have already started the process of relaunching their national economies.
We have the case in particular of initiatives that concern the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
It has to be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
It is time to transform the euro into a central tool of Europe, from support to a robust currency, but also to a real robust economy and to make the functioning of the euro follow.
Of mechanisms that ensure the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the essence, it is at the heart of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area has today an impact and a relevance that are unquestionable.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
It is necessary more.

Having a Lisbon strategy, which is a sum of national initiatives and a pact of stability and growth that differentiates the different countries it uses and that it has to subject, are limitations to which the limited budget we have is added.
As crises geram oportunidades.

The monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of the well-being of the member countries that integrate it, independently of their citizens, independently of the place where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, and that is why we are eagerly awaiting the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26th and present to European citizens.

It is essential that, from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by an effective prosperity made of cohesion and a citizenship that is also economic.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galiotta, on behalf of the Regional Development Committee of this Parliament, is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, it is necessary to make clear the reasons that lead the council to block the reform of the solidarity fund, as it is not able to reach an agreement on a common position that allows the continuation of the legislative process.
It is difficult to discern the reasons that may be underlying the position of the Council, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
The Council does not want a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters.
I do not want the council to give this type of solemn response to other types of catastrophes, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious public health situations.

It is important that these issues have a clear answer, as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks of this situation and whether it intends to take any measure aimed at unlocking the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
The citizens would not understand everything if we were not here.
I want to say that I wanted to protest against the statement that was made by Mrs. Lulling, which aims to condition the vote of the deputies in this House, and this conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation that is being made is an interpretation that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask the colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interest of citizens and the interest of countries that, in fact, vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, for two months, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Lisbon Treaty are hardly mentioned in the media.

Don't you think that now the information and communication strategy of the Commission should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are experiencing?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the powers of the world have at this time in their hands the international financial system.
They look for a hand detail and it was no longer without time.
And therefore, perhaps it is time to solve now another problem that we have heard for decades.
For decades we have heard this music of the ignoble plunder of resources, how many times, like now again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe that it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which they circulate and where the proceeds of this shameful exploitation of mineral resources are deposited at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I do not understand why these companies are not listed under the same title as the black list of terrorist organizations.
And I do not understand why the international community is not able to pursue these businessmen who are not businessmen, but are authentic bandits who endanger regional and world security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to take an international initiative in this regard. Thank you very much.
We have heard several times today that a crisis usually generates an opportunity, and that is the case.
And if we want to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to know.
First of all, we know at the level of the European Union the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in the financial markets.
E não é necessário que o senhor comissário Macri lance mais consultas, nem é preciso que a Presidência analise e evoco mais estudos.
For more proposals, just look at the proposals that were hastily made by the socialists and that many of them ended up being taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in the international space passively.

She has to be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. She has to be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are the tax havens at the moment.
Thirdly, we hear today here the President of the Commission say that there is reluctance in the coordination of strategies at the level of the different states.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that markets self-regulate, that the state should stay out.
That the financial markets do not have an impact on growth or employment. Perhaps there would be a more active and proactive spirit of solidarity among the different countries.
Mas hoje a proposta que temos em mãos é uma proposta que não passa de um primeiro passo. Se compararmos com o programa da China e dos Estados Unidos, por outro lado, ela.
The European Union does not define sufficiently clearly what the objective is, and the objective has to be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic, that protects them in times of crisis in terms of.
Solidarity, growth, and support programs for small and medium-sized enterprises that are not currently benefiting from the interventions made at the banking level.
The real economy is that, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is also here, and above all because of them. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, it is with particular satisfaction that I stand before you to present the work done, which, together with all of you, in this report, which was made together with all of you, in this report of initiative.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the development of this process, we can say that we did our job.

To all, especially to the shadow rapporteurs of the different political groups who have made great efforts to achieve commitments for the future, to the regional development staff, always available, namely Miguel Telkremedes and Elisa da Farra.

To the staff of the PS, to Lila and to Petros, to the European Commission, which, by always representing the many diverse general directions that such an encompassing report obliges, has permanently and closely followed the work and has made great efforts to ensure that it reaches a good port.
To my office and especially to Joana Benzinho, I sincerely thank you on behalf of the more harmonious and structured development for the coastal regions and for tourism in the European Union.
The twenty seven member states of the European Union together have more than eighty nine thousand kilometers of coastline.
This presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to their location, are marked by cosmopolitanism. If we talk about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen or Stockholm,

Due to the difficulties of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions with problems of connections to major cities or with accelerated contexts of desertification, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or the Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and experiences daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with it.
According to the available data up to 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas, these areas.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define the fifty kilometers in a straight line that go from the coast line to the inland areas.
Yes, regions and not maritime belts, detached from an integrated vision that both these articles lack and that our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, the entire population will focus on seeking opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, only hoping that they will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism on coastal areas has taken hold of our minds and led us to take action.

In the current context of financial crisis, in which the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly inescapable, tourism appears as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal way.

The regions that have a crushing or total dependence on this for their development see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust, especially because tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, specific measures can and should be taken, and the spirit in which the Lisbon Treaty was signed reflects this same tendency.
However, waiting until the moment the treaty comes into effect to start acting is like waiting for the phase when we will cry over spilled milk.
The present political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it require urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are structurally dependent on tourism as a promoter of employment, despite often being seasonal employment, this labor-intensive activity cannot be dismissed in the context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

Therefore, this report that we are now presenting to you, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Regional Development Commission of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, yes, to the numerous initiatives that it incorporates, as well as to those that it assumes its express support and that have already been advocated by other institutions, in addition to the measures taken in the emergency plan.

From the Commission, which I highlight the review of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock to which it is subject at this time must obviously be addressed.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport.

Energy, the instruments of cohesion are already on the ground, the new quality products policy that the PAC review incorporates with the announcement of the health check report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an adequate and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality in the near future in the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and a rapid and effective action involving all partners and stakeholders on the ground, we can ensure that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector. Thank you very much.
Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, the e-justice is an important step in access to the law, to justice and to the courts.
I want to congratulate myself with the initiative, congratulate the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The eJustice was one of the projects under discussion and it was Portugal's responsibility during its presidency to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens to access services from other member states in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable and in their own language.
This multilingual portal must be designed to serve citizens and companies seeking legal support and basic legal advice on cross-border legal issues.
The E Justice must be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit that will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and its articulation with this responsible unit.
Today, justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate myself on the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barrot, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, of the Shadow Martin, Rourke and of the other Shadows.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation establishing rules for biometric data devices on passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now we have needed to take new steps in the sense of combating the rapid and child trafficking.
The use of passports for children, according to the principle that one passport can be a fundamental means of overcoming this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of digital fingerprints in children from the age of six is already a practice with a long tradition, which perhaps does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that in this matter it is important to have harmonization.

It reassures me to know that the Member States, like Portugal, which for a long time defined as a minimum age the six years to proceed with the collection of fingerprints, will not have to change the national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of passports, which is reinforced today, is not exhausted by the existence of passports.

The passport alone corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which goes from the presentation of the necessary documents to the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to the verification and matching in the border control posts.
This report is one more step to affirm the rights of the person and guarantee their safety.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lambsdorff and the shadow rapporteurs, with a special mention for Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I consider it essential that we move forward in the direction of the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must effectively advance with the necessary specificities and precautions in the application of the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the competitions that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving Member States of the European Union.
But at the same time, we have to help in the development of conditions that allow greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in the world markets.

Comisario Macri, it seems to me important that with this directive, an advance can be made in the legal framework regarding public contracts in the fields of defense and security, advancing the construction of the internal market.

Internal and respecting, obviously, the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the area of security, and, namely, those that manufacture weapons, ammunition, safety and security equipment, such as my own country.

Mr. President, I would also like to underline the provisions that make it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises to access this market, namely through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of science advancing with greater impact and depth in the sector.

Industrial policy for the creation of a real European market in defense industries, which will also contribute to strengthening research and development not only in defense industries, but also in a set of European industries that depend on the development of defense industries.
To conclude, I think that we can refer to the obvious link between the defense industry and the Union's external policies.
But I would like to quote a recent intervention by Dettmann, translating a classic Roman saying: "Even peace prepares for war."

The European Union, as it is almost a peaceful superpower, we call these industries defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war, and therefore we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barrot, I agree with you. I agree with you on the dissatisfaction.
In fact, we have to be dissatisfied with the set of measures that are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe. The human trafficking continues. There are areas where there is a lot.
"Imigration, especially from the Mediterranean and towards Italy, France has made progress with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other member states have not done so."
It is necessary that the Commission continues without losing enthusiasm in this policy of cooperation and assistance to the United States.
Mr President, Madam Commissioner, I will try to put the issues in a very synthetic way.
First point, the issue of the special monitoring mechanism of the European Union for textiles, which ended or started here, as was said on December 31, 2008.
It is necessary, Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against any unfair practices and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I asked you to pay attention to this, like other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly obliges to comply with safety standards, social standards, environmental standards.
The REACH, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more conditions.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy and that it is perceptible and passable of monitoring so that imported products have identical requirements.
How is it that in the free trade agreements that are in progress, these aspects are being properly safeguarded?
E quanto ao meidine, pode o meidine ajudar de facto a resolver esta questão?
Third point, the European Union launched a plan for economic recovery to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy have in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a number of other countries, such as China, begin to increasingly proliferate the launch of non-tariff barriers so that our European imports do not access Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the updating or adjustment of the Globalization Fund, as well as the support available in the framework of structural funds, to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last question, finally, will the crisis we have gone through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner raise awareness? I end by raising awareness among your colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy in the sense of rebalancing. Thank you very much.

For us, it is clear that we must applaud. We must applaud the Obama decision, the Guantánamo closure decision, the prohibition of torture, the illegal interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, on the contrary.

It was precisely now with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luis Amado, that the possibility and duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without guilt formed in Guantánamo was triggered.

This is truly important. This is what should be highlighted as an example for the remaining member states of the European Union. How important it is that tomorrow the resolution is approved by the group of parties that make up this chamber, so that the decision can have more strength in unity.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you very much to my colleague from Naples for the excellent report.

Fourteen years after Barcelona and five years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean with economic power, parliamentary power, civil society, and heads of government deciding together.
Everyone with the desire to do more and better in a territory where seven hundred and twenty million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
Signos apenas ao lado económico e empresarial é um erro claro.

Giving an answer to growth crises naturally requires a political response, but giving an answer to humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens have to give answers to the problems of the world.
The world asked for answers and months later, we are still citizens and politicians, especially on a platform like the Union for the Mediterranean, taking too long to react.
I hope that at least this moment has served to learn and move forward. After all, only those who make mistakes learn, but advancing in the speed of reaction is absolutely crucial.

The interest in the approval of this directive of this proposal directive essentially lies in the way it can contribute to dynamizing economic activity at the local level and supporting social actions.
This application of a reduced rate has great importance in the housing sector, both in construction and renovation, allowing member states to adopt it to reduce the respective cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, especially by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the IVA rate, securing and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thus stimulating the economy itself.
The restoration activity, fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the very increase of tourism, can thus gain a lot on the local level with this reduction of VAT.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the internal European market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified in the Council's plan.
Por isso, não posso concordar com a extensão desta taxa reduzida a equipamentos, seja qual for o pretexto.

The prudent way this proposal should be treated in the European Parliament should not give pretexts to governments that have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal to use, in practice, the veto right that European legislation still competes with them in tax matters.
And so, here, one must prudently reject changes that significantly hinder the acceptance of the text.
As already mentioned, not only is the best enemy of the good, but also those who want everything lose everything.
This directive proposal is important not only for the strengthening of local economies, but also for the ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
Therefore, we support the Commission's proposal as it was presented. In fact, this was the sense of the vote, as agreed by the Commission for the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

I greet the work of the rapporteurs and I appeal for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it was presented to the Commission and voted on in the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
I had the floor to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and it was, in fact, this that motivated me to speak when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech presidency.
Nobody wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend women who are ignored, despised, discriminated against because they want to dedicate themselves to the family and we do not listen to them.
And this is a question of freedom. It is a question of freedom, of choice, which the left so much likes to evoke, but which it forgets here.
Is it about respecting or not respecting the orientation freedom of couples?
It is about being able to provide to those who want to do so, more quality of life, more paternity and more maternity of quality.
This is what our society also needs to do.
We are not going there, we will not solve the problems of birth and happiness of people with prejudices.
We solve with policies adjusted to reality and to the spontaneous desires of people.
We are not going there with an obsession with the state and the market.
Let's take a fair look at the family.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the difficult situation in Kymonda was aggravated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian government to also act with a great sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving Munich's facilities will have a decisive impact on the units of Vila do Conde and Dresde.

The Portuguese Minister of Economy, Manuel Pinho, stated the great interest in making this company, so important for Portugal and Europe, viable, referring that Qimonda can be a competitive company at the global level.
President, we must continue the efforts of the Portuguese government in the direction of a solution that guarantees the viability of the company.
We hope that the German governments at the federal and state levels will effectively work to resolve this problem.
As for me, I would like to emphasize again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry in the European territory.
That no national or state executive commits the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs in the Union's territory.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help the restructuring of the large automobile industry groups, but the funds of the Union and the energies of the European Commission cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Dear Commissioner, to commit the Commission to supporting Kimondo, overcoming possible communication failures is the support we provide to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, to whom we are politically linked, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and a significant part of the Kimondo workers.

We must emphasize before concluding that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was a new hope regarding the Kimondo and it is important to refer to the importance, as has already been done by colleagues in the economic sector in which Kimondo operates.
We take into account, as soon as the Portuguese government manifests itself available to support the IMF with whatever is necessary, meeting the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save the Amazon. Time is of the essence.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we live in are perhaps not the right ones to talk about the Lisbon Strategy, but without a doubt we need a strategy.
A strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis poses for us.
And this is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not turn away from this issue and has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the Länder of Germany.

It is essential to keep in mind that this is an industry, as has already been said, that concerns Europe for its quality and value, for the research it develops, for the environmental quality that is also associated with it, and it is essential that the Commission does not turn away.
I second my colleague Penedo's invitation for the Commissioner and the Commission to travel to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission be aware that at this time, Europeans are looking at Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands before they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and to get to work, helping them to overcome the difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I would like to add my words to the tributes to Jean Moulin, but I would like to take the floor to greet the President for his statement made on the occasion of the European Day in memory of the victims of terrorism.
It was my proposal that five years ago we adopted this orientation that the council consecrated in a meeting on March 25 following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
Mas a minha intervenção era um apelo.

The Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately, this date has not yet had, in the set of European institutions and Member States, the projection it should have.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to honor the victims, as the president did, but also to raise the level of public opinion awareness.
I know that there are celebrations in Madrid today, but little more.
And therefore, the appeal that I make to the Commission and the Czech Presidency is that all Member States celebrate this date in the future. Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we predict.
There are good reasons to suppose that the European stimulus provided is not enough, but it is clear that it is taking too long to reach citizens.
The position of the Parliament is strong and clear, it has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs with cohesion, with solidarity, whether territorial or social.
And in this moment of crisis, citizens cannot settle for a Europe that does not give them an answer, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems that are plaguing it.
What will the Parliament ask the Commission?

Naturally, through these reports, it requests that it coordinates national interventions, asks it to use all the means that are at its disposal to intervene, and gives it all the conditions as a budgetary entity for this to happen.

Ask him to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tell him that it is important to have a schedule with a calendar to implement the measures of regulation of the financial market, as well as to provide real economy with credit.
But what is asked of the council?
It is asked of the Council to above all, rediscover the political will that is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there cannot be a single market without this guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
That is why we all delegated at the European level the national autonomies that we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone who visits sub-Saharan Africa easily recognizes, in general, the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that those services should serve.
The indicators continuously disclosed at the international level do not cease to confirm it.
And in this regard, it is absolutely disturbing to think that simple gestures and even not very elaborate practices, not even particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives.

The European financial support can be crucial in this regard and we must always keep in mind that cooperation in the health area is truly strategic and directly affects not only one of the Millennium Development Goals, but many of the Millennium Development Goals.

Now the Court of Auditors considered that, I quote, the Community funding for the health sector has not increased since the year 2000 in proportion to its total aid to development, despite the commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
End of quote.

And he acknowledged, I quote again, the Commission made a significant contribution through its financing to establish the World Fund for the Fight against AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not give the same attention to the strengthening of health systems, which was expected to be one of its priorities.
End of quote.

According to the court, this will have happened again because the commission did not have enough experience in health matters to ensure that the funding for the aid granted to this sector was used in the best way.
End of quote.
This is therefore a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors launches directly to the European Commission and that I follow.
On our side, I want to reiterate this same challenge, now supported by the objectivity of these data and this assessment.
The health services are already part, but they should become more and more part of our development priorities, being worthy of an increase in their financing.

Optimizing the way help is provided, while presenting the apparently antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is to provide a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge, and it is in this sense that I urge it.
Colleague Boies recently made a touching intervention here and was able to put human faces in the coldness of these numbers of the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Commissioner, is to be able to put a look of joy and hope on the same faces.
And for this, Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the health area in our cooperation be different.
President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly difficult situation.
It is a country that has been experiencing chronic instability for many years, which has tried a path to democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well. There was a coup, a war, a small internal war, and they are living in great political, military, and social instability, and now, recently, also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers of interest in drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the death by bomb of the Chief of Staff, Tagme Naoe, and also the murder, in terms particularly barbaric, not to say savage, of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we strongly condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normality and the lesson that I take and would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Samane Manet and General Verissimo Seabra, it was as if the eyes were closed to the fact that the culprits were not found and brought to justice.
It is evident that this is not a solution.
And therefore, we must make it clear to the state of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the culprits must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the necessary help.

I would also like to draw attention to the concern with which we saw the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk that this also represents for the European Union, and the shocking evidence of its presence in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal that we treat in this context the relationship with Cape Verde.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable. And this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all the work celebrated.

The three lines defined in the Green Book, concentration, interconnection and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with the.

The concentration of economic activity, the inequalities in terms of access to markets and services resulting from distance and divisions imposed, whether by the borders between member states, especially the most disadvantaged ones, but also between regions.
We must thus promote the improvement of the synergies between these policies with methods of effective evaluation of their territorial impact.

Therefore, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, the GDP continues to be the only criterion of eligibility to receive support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the carrying out of territorial assessments should not be the origin of more bureaucracy or delays, but rather the simplification in the application of new policies and support actions for territorial cohesion.

The fifth report between Calari and to finish, Madam President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions located between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is necessary to pay attention that these regions need to have a clearer status, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Commissioner. Dear colleagues, in the context of this great debate on territorial cohesion and the future of the economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problem of the outermost regions.

Regions, due to the conjugation and permanence of a series of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in the context of a serious international crisis, such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would like to appeal to the European Commission and especially to Commissioner Hubner to pay very special attention to the effects of the current crisis in the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the peripheral regions, particularly in tourism, construction and unemployment, would be important to allow for a specific European response to these regions.

Therefore, I challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis in the outermost regions that goes beyond the measures already announced in the context of the economic and social cohesion policy for the generality of the European regions.
A European response specific to the crisis for the most vulnerable regions.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, in response to the global financial crisis, the European economic relationship plan states that the cohesion policy significantly contributes to public investment by the Member States and regions, acting as a form of recovery from the current crisis.
Specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of Lisbon's strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments are aimed at achieving this purpose and accelerating the achievement of results.

In this regard, the expansion of the scope of the European Social Fund and the European Social Fund has a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple social and economic emergency situations that lack support.
I am certain today, as in the past, that your action will be more effective the more complementary your actions and areas are.

However, as the availability of new funds or new lines of action on the ground was not foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and the rapid increase in competitiveness pressure in the European economy resulting from the current financial and economic crisis.

I would like to point out that the REGI Commission has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for the improvement of the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission is now proposing.
It was urgently requested, however, in this matter and in the adoption of this regulatory package, we took it into account and this cause never failed to assume its political responsibilities.

Por isso, apesar de muitas serem as visões que a particularidade do momento suscita, a bem das garantias de celeridade do processo e do real benefício para os cidadãos que a proposta pretende, abstemos-nos de por ora apresentar novas propostas e alterações.
However, we have alerted to the need to start immediately a process of evaluation of this fund, with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you.
Senhora Presidente, a crise, entre outros aspectos, permitiu evidenciar os Fortes desequilíbrios entre os países da zona euro, talvez a principal.
Conclusion of the report of the Economic and Monetary Union to ten, but above all the extreme vulnerability of the countries that belong to the European Union, but do not belong to the eurozone.

Therefore, the reinforcement of available means at the European level to support payment balance crisis situations is absolutely essential. And that is why we welcome the transition from twelve to twenty-five and then to fifty million euros of necessary means.
However, more importantly, it is to attack the deep causes of the problems and not only their most evident manifestations.
Today, a wider Europe and the eurozone have to reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of real cohesion and convergence.
It is necessary to see in this light what is the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also necessary to review new financing instruments, such as the eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from being sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. President in office, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not the time to discuss internally the way we organize ourselves, so my votes are that the Lisbon Treaty be quickly ratified so that we can face the world scene united and solidary as Europeans.
Regarding the economic crisis, in the report that I authored and that this Parliament approved by a majority, it was admitted that the recovery plan presented by the Commission was not sufficient.
Today we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that began financially extends to the real economy, to employment, and to social issues.
E ele não é suficiente e está desfocado.

Cada crise encerra uma oportunidade. Esta é a oportunidade da Comissão responder aos verdadeiros problemas dos europeus através de uma regulação financeira séria e não da mais leve e parcelar que for.

Possible, how is it in progress? Not made of national and individualistic plans, but of a true European initiative, not through dispersed means, but concentrating on the real challenge that I undertake.

In each crisis, there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens, and I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the relaunch plan. Thank you very much.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express, not only on behalf of the PPE, as has already been done by many Members, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese Members of the PPE, my great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the development and evolution perspectives of the European Union, which creates conditions for a new stage.

We would like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Lisbon Treaty, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President Commissioner here present, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

The Czech Republic has played a very important role here, and that is why we would like to say that we are also pleased to see that, despite all these vicissitudes and still looking forward to the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of its capital linked.

A decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also compare this perspective with another flag, which will also be a flag of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, which is the flag of the national parliaments.
We believe that the Lisbon Treaty takes a decisive step in the direction of incorporating the presence of national parliaments into European democracy.
E por isso julgamos que essa dimensão, que é a dimensão mais importante da democracia, que é a dimensão representativa e não como às vezes ouvimos nesta Câmara, a dimensão referendária, aquilo que é.

The fundamental and essential element of democracy is representation and not direct voting. The Treaty of Lisbon is also a great step in the direction of increasing the participation of representative national democracies in the European process.
Por isso estamos muito satisfeitos com esta decisão do povo irlandês.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to celebrate the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and next Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in taking the lead in this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union closer to its citizens became very evident.
They are, we are all the main recipients of the Union's action.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our daily lives.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
It is surely the case of the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be simultaneously a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, after a long debate about its organization and functioning, will be able to focus much more and with much more effective new instruments on the real problems that Europeans face, competitiveness, growth and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Mrs. Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Considering the deficit of information on the values, competences, objectives and mode of functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new discipline of European studies of a compulsory nature.
In an objective, true and concrete way, young Europeans will know our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through the knowledge of these young people that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and the enormous usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission. I begin by greeting you in this first debate for what this new political control instrument means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is the European citizens, through their representatives, who are the ones gaining.

Taking into account the most recent developments, the Irish referendum, the ratification by Poland, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask for your assessment on the process of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.
There have been delegations by the President of the Commission.
E qual é a previsão que faz para uma eventual data de entrada em vigor do Tratado e, por outro lado, saber se neste momento e em função dessa previsão, a Comissão.
Already some transition duties of the treaty of Nice for the treaty of Lisbon or if it is still in a phase, let's say, of expectation, therefore, in a phase of waiting to see.

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard this, I would like to know the following: in this phase in which everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, in the end, what is the perspective that you have?
It is whether we will now have until this final ratification by the Czech Republic, a management commission, or whether we will proceed with the appointment procedures for the new commissioners.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service concretizes the efforts of the European institutions, ensuring the creation of an effective service capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It must still represent more than the parts that constitute it. It must be an added value in relation to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the Union's specificity is at the center of this new reality, and that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which defends and safeguards a close articulation between the Commission and the future service.

I wanted to highlight two aspects for this purpose, the importance of close coordination between the Commission President and the High Representative, also Vice President of the Commission, to ensure their effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, the need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is announced and that can compromise the effective functioning of the service.
The Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a center of excellence representative of the best skills in external policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Commissioner. First of all, I would like to emphasize the importance of this issue that was raised by the Member for Glorens, because it is a question of the most fundamental justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a situation of a flu pandemic, it will be the southern countries that will suffer the most from this problem and from the consequences of the proliferation of the virus, and not the northern countries.

And we watch every year with total passivity the death of millions of citizens and citizens as a result of pandemics that have already been eradicated or are being treated in the northern countries. An immense list of malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits to this list and we watch this problem with compassion.

We effectively use the countries of the South as suppliers, free of charge, of samples of the new strains of the virus, so that we can improve the treatment in the countries of the North. However, we have not been able to effectively address these problems and, therefore, the issues that were raised, I would like to add a few more.
We want to effectively address this problem as a public health problem or as a business.
Because if it is a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world and for this, the efforts have to be more effective.
Por outro lado, gostaria de perguntar e espero que não seja o caso se estamos à espera que, afinal, os estoques das vacinas na Europa fiquem tão sobrelotados.
Que os efeitos secundários se revelem tão negativos neste plano para isso, sim, termos um ato de generosidade e repentinamente começamos a enviar as necessárias vacinas para os países do sul.

And finally, I just wanted to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans, if the Commission feels comfortable with a system or a model where the northern countries deal with pandemics through a prevention model and the southern countries deal with palliatives or just leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I want to express my full support for the issue raised by Mr. Roy and above all, to highlight the underlying issue, the underlying political issue that is at stake here in this matter, which has to do precisely with the joint investigation program.

What happened in the joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases, and in particular on Alzheimer's, was that, in the course of the process, the rules changed. We stopped having a report, we started having a resolution, so our capacity for co-decision in this matter was eliminated. We stopped being deputies, we started being consultants.
And therefore, I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one, and in this sense, the role of parliament must be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they must be scorned, that they must be transparent, that they must be democratic.
What happened to the process regarding the joint decision and joint programming of the investigation on Alzheimer's? It is a process that should not be repeated and if it is.

Repetir, por favor, que avisem com tempo. Espero por isso que a última coisa que NOS pode acontecer é que não sejam consideradas as decisões e as recomendações que o Parlamento apresentou nesta matéria.
Thank you. In the last month, the regions of Europe have been particularly evident.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities consolidated the position of regions as a fundamental part of the European response to global challenges.
Thus concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Szmrecski, and the hundreds of debates that ensued.

Also at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of the Presidents of the European Union's Trans-European Regions, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constituted a milestone in regional policy in support of European construction.
The global challenges and European responses constitute an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the EU.

These regions, such as the Azores, in addition to the permanent constraints that we are all accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that provide clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new essential domains in response to global challenges.

And said, therefore, that the President of the Commission should put an end to the palatial coup that the Commission's new paper indicates was being prepared while we, deputies and European citizens, were apologizing for the ratification of the Lisbon Treaty and its importance in the defense of the cohesion of the territory.
I would like, first of all, to greet the rapporteurs, namely Mr Martin and Mr Corbett, and to say that, as a member of the PPE, I basically review the proposed changes to the regulation.
I would like to emphasize the point that I find important here and that has not yet been brought up here tonight, which is the point of the national parliaments.

The democratic reinforcement of the European Parliament results, without a doubt, from this regulation and the Lisbon Treaty, but European democracy also results from the connection to national parliaments.
And what this proposal is now doing is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the very instruments of the European Parliament, its instruments of control, its legislative capacity, and, on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of the national parliaments through different instruments.
And that is why I am here, let's say, fully in tune with the proposals made.
I do not agree with my colleague Duff when he understands that we should leave the interruption of the mechanisms of relations with the national parliaments for later.
I believe that we can do it already under the Treaty of Lisbon and that this is very important.
I also wanted to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brok regarding representation in COSAC and that I am finally.
Completely in solidarity with the observations made here by my colleague Brok and other colleagues on the primacy of Parliament and Members of Parliament over the services of Parliament.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the rapporteur colleague on the work developed in this report and on her intervention of a few moments ago.
This new microfinance instrument will allow the granting of microcredit to small businesses and people who have lost their job and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important in a period in which it is expected that the economic crisis will result in the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.
As a result of the economic downturn, banks have stopped lending for the creation of jobs and companies, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now this new means of microfinancing will counteract this current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the obtaining of necessary funds for the launch of new companies and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate one hundred million euros from the program budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is equally a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of resources from progress aimed at the most vulnerable groups is not necessarily the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, it is proposed to create a separate budgetary item to finance this instrument, as well as an increase in funding to one hundred and fifty million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group are the vulnerable groups that have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups must be eliminated.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that people have financial support and also have adequate training. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by greeting the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the PPE.
Our assessment of the Swedish presidency is one of a practically absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
The first in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency to the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty for the very successful election of the Commission President.
Namely, all issues related to ratification were extremely professional and met the highest standards expected of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Lisbon Treaty, this contribution of the Swedish presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the work of the Commission was also very important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many deputies of the PPE, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has been most successful.
The Swedish Presidency, and especially the Commission Presidency, have made a great effort to ensure that the EU is at the forefront of the fight against climate change.
We consider this balance also very positive.

A third point is the financial regulation point, which, especially with this last council, has taken a step that we consider decisive and that can have a very significant impact on the exit from the crisis.
And therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on this achievement of having obtained an agreement in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a few words for an area that personally means a lot to me, which is the Stockholm Programme and therefore the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I who accompanied it, want the temper process, especially after the AIE process, I consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish presidency and the Prime Minister Reinfeldt for this.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, for the recognition of professional qualifications. It was consolidated into a single legislative act, as is known, fifteen directives, which originated various problems of indolence in the application in the different Member States.
The difficulties are known and the Commission must inventory the critical points and make an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market device.
The protectionism that manifests itself at various levels constitutes an obstacle not only to the free circulation of people, but also to the internal market.
We must try to identify the nebulous points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by distrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is an effort to facilitate the achievement that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
A improvement of the application of this directive will have to go through a disclosure of the recognition of qualifications in the Solvit network and in the EURES network by the incentive of.
De plataformas comuns, implementação de pontos de contacto eficazes e não menos importante, deverá proporcionar uma articulação desta diretiva com a diretiva de serviços.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is urgent that a debate be promoted on the Community budget and how it can in the future contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, crucial values for regions like Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore require permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking and constructing cohesion policy.

The Commission has referred on several occasions to some aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and more guidance for achieving results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
Mas há questões que me suscitam alguma preocupação, sobretudo tendo em consideração as necessidades das regiões ultraperiféricas.
In this article, allow me three brief notes. First, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as the added value sectors.

A reorientation like this can call into question objective two, which currently benefits about two-thirds of the European regions, in addition to potentially being counterproductive in regions with economic profile and very specific competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that the maintenance of the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

Deve continuar a privilegiar-se numa alocação e gestão dos fundos estruturais sob uma perspetiva regional e não nacional ou mesmo centralizada a nível europeu. Em terceiro e último lugar, mas não menos importante, gostaria de recordar e sublinhar o artigo 349.
The 349 Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions in terms of access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.
Agravada por condicionalismos e características únicas de caráter perene, as quais se manifestam nas tais dificuldades constantes e que, por isso, exigem as reclamadas ajudas permanentes.
Thank you, Mr. President, in view of the urgency, what we are witnessing in Copenhagen are several steps backwards.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than any other, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation where each one for himself, where each state can define what its goals are and, on top of that, in a voluntary regime.
To refer that we have a goal of two degrees centigrade or goals for financing without any clarification, can also not serve as a consolation.
And therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future and acting in terms of the future is to stop going from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always said so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, not defining or defending the goals that he claimed were his and that he would not give up.

And therefore, what I ask is whether in the future we will be fairer, whether we will continue to allow that, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest continue to pay the highest price.
Thank you. Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to report here what is happening in Portugal at this moment, where it is clear that social communication.
Brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which calls into question freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mario Crespo, saw his chronicle censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister Jose Socrates must provide substantial explanations to the country. He must explain that he is not dominating, censoring, or suppressing freedom of expression in Portugal.

In the way we are going, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a state of formal law, where the Prime Minister is limited to formalities, procedures, formalities, and does not want to give substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a state of material law.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The Green Book for the reform of the common fisheries policy, whose rapporteur is my colleague from the Azores, Mr. Duarte, and Mr. Neves, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector that plays a major role in the balance of local development in the outermost regions.

The forestry sector follows the ongoing discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal fleets and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend a principle of positive discrimination in the matter of limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone, only to local artisanal fleets.
In Madeira, the priority is the support for the modernization of vessels, as well as management that ensures the long-term conservation of a broad group of species.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for the economic, environmental, and social balance.
Finally, we will fight for permanent and undated support for fisheries in the outermost regions.
This report on the Federe aims to extend the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support was only applied to marginalized communities that resided in the urban areas of the new member states.
In other words, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace poor quality housing.
It is essentially about how to vaccinate and give the Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.

I also salute the equality of treatment for all Member States, because marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding this important report on the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid application in the framework of the economic recovery plan is also achieved, responding in a timely manner to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, allow me to start by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nieuwstegroe, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he has always shown to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the Federe regulation, which are of particular importance for the so-called former member states and also for Portugal.
These changes will allow the use of the FEDER in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be attributed to urban development operations.

The amendments that I proposed together with other colleagues and that were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Commission will allow the former member states, and not just the new ones, as provided for in the original proposal, to also benefit from this possibility of financing.
With this, I tried to prevent the opening of a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the former Member States of this and probably other additional uses of community aid.
What would make no sense, since the problems of a housing nature, especially between marginalized communities, exist both in the new and in the old Member States.

I would like to reiterate that the antiquity of accession to the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be immediately abandoned.

The negotiation of the cohesion policy after 2013 should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion and should be oriented to reward, instead of punish, the regions that have shown themselves to be exemplary in the use of community aid.
I would like to emphasize to the Commission and the President of the Commission the way they have worked with this Parliament over the past months of investiture.
There is no body in the world with executive and legislative initiative capacity that is subject to presentation by its president of a program before the parliament, to hearing with all the groups.

Parliamentarians to a vote by an absolute and expressive majority to bring here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions with answers.

Someone who agreed to negotiate with the parliament a framework agreement in which he accepted, first of all, to justify and expand the powers of the parliament in the field of legislative initiative.

That accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action or in international negotiations, that accepted taking into account the opinion of the Parliament on the Commissioners on the remodeling of the Commissioners.
This means once and for all, from my point of view, that the Commission has shown from July to now that it is willing to have a close connection with Parliament and that it is.

To do so, he clearly and unequivocally demonstrated that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method, of which colleague Saryusz-Wojowski spoke, is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
E por isso a Comissão e o Acordo quadro merecem o integral apoio do PPE.

I would like to point out that in the insular regions, air transport is sometimes the only possibility of access and that the operating conditions are conditioned by the size of its passenger and cargo flows.
