Thank you very much, Mr. President. I take the floor today in this chamber with a voice emboldened by the consternation of those who lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that occurred in the past Saturday in Madeira.

My words are obviously to associate myself with the feeling of pain and grief that affected the families of the deceased, which at this moment number forty-two, to whom I pay my tribute and respect for their losses.

The true dimension of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, or perhaps the search and rescue teams that have been working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that they salute, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
And I fear that the number of victims may increase.
The scenario is of a large-scale destruction, with high material damage in access routes, roads and bridges completely destroyed and in essential services such as water and electricity supply.
There are about six hundred people who have been displaced and lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
But we must now look ahead.
I also need to give a message of solidarity, hope and confidence to people.
It is necessary to help and it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament, in particular, have a word. They are fundamental in the mobilization process of the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we have to do it quickly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us the most.

I appeal here to the Commission and to Mr. President Barroso, especially to the Commissioner for Regional Development, Mr. Juhanes, and I greet your initiative to visit the forest in the shortest possible time.
Asking him to be also a bearer of this message of hope, of help and support to reconstruction, because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again took from us.
But I am sure that we will do it, because, as the hymn of the wood taught me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who, between rock and hard labor, have tilled the land, the heroes of work in the mountain range.
Through wood, you will honor your history and in the path of work, you will fight and achieve your well-being and glory.
We begin today's plenary session with a minute of silence.

And it was a minute of silence, with two meanings, the solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that devastated the wood and their families, and a sense of homage to all the workers who have tirelessly provided aid to these victims.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that goes beyond the one we are doing here.
What we see in the wood is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change causes extreme events to occur more frequently and we must have responses for them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we should not be condemned to have their effects always so dramatic for people's lives.
That is why we must fight for planning and organization policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to conclude, Mr. President, that what is most important and that brought us here, which is the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European institutions, must have the capacity to give an urgent response to an urgent situation, and for this, the necessary financial resources and the necessary speed are required.
A tribute of solidarity to the relatives and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday on the island of Madeira.

As a member of the European Parliament, I cannot fail to express my support for the Parliament and the Union's active demonstration of solidarity in favor of the autonomous region of Madeira and its people.

It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and it is precisely in these moments that its solidarity is most needed, and it is also most important that it is made to be felt.

I also want to show solidarity with the pain of the people of Madeira and insistently ask the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, to unlock all available means, all means at their disposal, to provide this assistance.
I would also like to point out that when there is a misfortune of this kind, it is much more difficult to attack its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and regions.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this gravity in poor countries and in poor regions, and in particular in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case of Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were planned and requested and that were here mentioned in relation to the solidarity fund, no longer be expected.

That it immediately affects function because due to climate change, these processes unfortunately will be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that live in torrential regimes in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Commissário e Conselho estamos aqui a falar da reinvenção do sistema energético para a escala Europeia através do investimento nas tecnologias de baixo carbono.

Energético a micro geração a distribuição e a formas diferentes de distribuição e de projetos diferentes que não tenham de passar apenas pelas grandes estruturas e o acesso à energia.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there is still a need to talk about what seems to me to be an absolutely important point, which is the tone that is permanently placed in public-private partnerships, as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, the Commission tells us that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am no longer enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

And therefore, this bet on public-private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are surely certain that not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that it is public partnerships that are public or private, we know from the outset who will pay.
Who will pay? It is the taxpayers. At the beginning, it is the consumers who, by chance, are also taxpayers in the end.
And we know that those who pay less and at the outset are the institutions and private organizations that make the investments, are remunerated by him, but in the end end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, what seems to me is that once again we are systematically passing on to future generations the bill of the change of the European energy model.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union recently celebrated, within the framework of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on imports of bananas from these countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has direct negative effects on European banana producers, namely on the banana producers of Madeira in Portugal, but also, and even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I would like to remind you that the situation of the producers of these regions is already seriously complicated by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and by the size of their explorations, which leads them to have to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of banana, wood, and canary producers, taking into account the serious immediate impact that the new Geneva agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and commercialization of bananas from these ultraperipheral regions.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political, and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.

Fragilizados e endividados estados não têm capacidade de proteger os seus cidadãos.

When the Economic and Monetary Union completed ten years, the Commission considered the euro the most successful project of the Union.
Today we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis has shown that the economic and monetary union is an unfinished project.
The minimum rescue measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be deceived, the conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main.
The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
We have to face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not just a mere cooperation between countries.
It is an unfinished process that at this moment either strengthens or runs very serious risks of disappearing.
There are three issues that have to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this climate of emergency. It is necessary to create a monetary fund.

European Union. It is necessary to advance with the eurobond. It is necessary to advance with the architecture of European supervision and regulation, and it is necessary to advance with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The one percent growth forecasted for the European Union is unsustainable in terms.
Want from its demographic composition, want in terms of combating unemployment. The 2020 strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas that do not have means of implementation.

Third dimension, Commissioner Olli Rehn, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences between the Member States that make up the Union. The policy of convergence must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and for the deposit of citizens' savings.
Here, exactly in the powers and competencies of the banking authority, lies the ability to implement a new strategy for managing cross-border crises in the banking sector, the subject of my report.
It is not up to us to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is done.
De forma ordenada, limitando os efeitos colaterais no resto do sistema e, sobretudo, evitando que seja o contribuinte a pagar os custos das crises que eles geram.

For this, a set of new devices is necessary. It is necessary to adopt common rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology for all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to make an assignment of extended powers of intervention to the supervisors.
It is necessary to design clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in an institution in difficulty.
It is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
Todo este processo para vinte e sete Estados membros requer tempo.
Meanwhile, about fifty of the twelve thousand banks operating in Europe represent seventy percent of the assets.

Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating within the framework of national supervisory colleges.
It is possible and urgent that they, according to the risk they generate, begin to make contributions to a fund that finances the eventual interventions.
That are necessary and it is important that the banking authority create a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in the event of difficulty in these banks.
In its entirety, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coherent.
Different countries and, above all, that a principle as expensive as that in Europe is fulfilled, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are borne by the polluter himself.
This proposal fits perfectly into what we are discussing, especially in the competencies of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was a very large majority in favor of this proposal, eighty-seven percent of the votes.
We also count here in the plenary with the massive vote of this institution in the sense of supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic.
Let's take action that is urgent and necessary to revive the hope of Europeans in Europe, in their financial system, and in particular in the banking system. Thank you very much.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems of the planet, and every year we lose thirteen million hectares of forest, thus contributing to twenty percent of the carbon emissions of the globe and constituting a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, is very responsible for the occurrence of extreme and drought events, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
The loss of forests puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and this impact are not distributed equally by all of us.
The communities with fewer resources and the communities that rely more on the forest and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation concerns our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local communities and indigenous peoples, and social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is the illegal logging of wood, which accounts for twenty to forty percent of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from producing countries to consuming countries of the same wood.
This illegal practice puts at risk the sustainable exploitation of wood and the companies that do it.
Nice words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consistent measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the prohibition of trade in wood.
Good intentions are not enough.
Effective means are needed, namely sanctions that, in this case, may be of three types.

First, coimas that are withdrawn, in fact, the economic benefit of the illegal practice, aggravated by recurrence. Second, confiscation of the wood of the products in question. Third, immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out a commercial activity.

And so it is because those who explore or commercialize a natural resource must be socially responsible, and it is also the case that those who place wood or wood products for the first time in the European Union must be required to take measures to ensure that it is wood that has been legally explored.
That is why all the following operators must provide basic information about this wood, namely its provenance and its destination.
The population should still have the right and I end here, Mr. President, the right to have access to information about who complies and who does not comply. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Europe needs to renew confidence and hope.
In an unprecedented crisis, we had the firefighters, as Jacques de Launay said.
We hope that the Belgian presidency will bring the architects.
The first test, of course, will be in September, already the approach of the Council to the proposals of the Parliament regarding the financial architecture.

Cutting off today structural funds, as proposed by the Commission, which were created to stimulate convergence in diverging economies, seems to be like putting out a fire that is not yet extinguished.
We clearly need architects.

One last question, I would like to know the external dimension of the action of the European Union, in particular, to know a little more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancun and Doha.

Thank you, Mr. President. This report on the initiative that we are discussing today, on the responsibility of Mr. Beuve, to whom I congratulate on the way he led it and on the good final result, and in which I had the privilege of being shadowing and negotiating the seventeen commitments obtained, is absolutely essential at a time when.

As políticas agrícolas se encontram cada vez mais orientadas para os mercados. Os agricultores se vêem confrontados na Europa com níveis de rendimento muito baixos e milhões de consumidores em resultado da crise que a todos afeta. Se têm se vêem na premente necessidade de manter os alimentos a preços acessíveis.

That is why, if the farmers' incomes are increasingly going to depend on the values generated in the markets and the price of food for their proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain.
It becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable distribution of the value added, from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair returns for some and adequate prices for others.

To achieve this, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships that are established throughout the food supply chain, to give them transparency, ensuring the existence of a framework of good, loyal, and competitive practices.
In this regard, we appeal to the Commission to take into account the proposals widely supported by the Committee on Agriculture.
A few days ago in Arouca, Portugal, all the workers of a shoe company were fired by a simple text message without further explanation.
I bring up this case because it is, unfortunately, a blatant example of the abuses of collective dismissals in Europe.
It goes against all European norms and undermines any sense of common sense, respect, and dignity.
Since the crisis began, Europe has had nine new eight million unemployed, for a total of twenty-five million. How many have been laid off in such a shameful way as this?
I would say more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union says it is bearer of a long tradition of safeguarding workers' rights.
However, the current legislation has not been effective.
Therefore, what additional measures will the Commission take?
This is why this issue is so relevant.
There is no justification for dismissals like Arouca's.
It will be an innovation to say goodbye by SMS, but it is not a good innovation, it is a terrible one. Surely, thank you very much.
The environmental catastrophe under debate today, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns all of us, European citizens.
The notion of sustainable development, in which we believe, is a concept that has no administrative borders, religious creeds, and looks at the planet as a whole, and not as the sum of its parts.
The Jordan River is therefore a problem of all humanity and not only of the populations or communities directly affected by the scarcity or low quality of its water.
Think globally, act locally.
This is what we are doing today here to make people think globally.
While the European Union, we must help to act locally as a way to minimize and reverse this permanent degradation of the flow and quality of the waters of the Jordan River.
And to act or help act, the Union already has legislative, institutional framework and instruments at its disposal.
I refer to the Union for the Mediterranean, to its secretariat and to the FEMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is obviously a topic that the delegation of this parliament, which I preside over, will follow closely in its relations with the countries of the Mashreq.
It is obvious that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy must first be undertaken by the states and local authorities whose populations directly benefit from it.
In this area, I would like to underline two ideas present in the resolution.
First, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River, consisting of representatives of the states or authorities that use those waters.
E aqui a Europa poderá ajudar partilhando, por exemplo, a experiência da Comissão Internacional para a Proteção do Rio Reno.
Secondly, the support and dissemination of good practices in the field of joint community projects involving Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian citizens.
Namely, those promoted by the Friends of the Middle East, which the colleague de Rossi just now invoked, regarding the efficient and correct management of the water resources of the Jordan Valley.
Finally, Mr. President, and in an even broader context, to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this term conveys.

At the moment, although lamenting the absence of the European Union in the process, we greet and encourage the resumption of the new direct dialogue process between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. We would like to welcome this direct involvement of both parties.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. The coordination of efforts in the European Semester, which was the subject of yesterday's analysis at Ecofin, is in itself positive, but it is only a part of the reality.

It is important that the European Monetary Fund is created.
It is necessary to treat sovereign debt alongside all other obligations required for participation in a monetary area, and it is necessary.

I believe that the evolution of this work should not be in the direction of the dangerous idea of sanctions, and I count on Commissioner Barnier and his experience to help the Commission move in this direction.
A second note to sincerely congratulate him on the work carried out in financial supervision.
I think that Commissioner Barnier, in particular, together with this Parliament and the Belgian Presidency, managed to reach a good agreement, an agreement that honors us.
And that it defends the interests of European citizens and my votes are that the agenda that is missing should follow the same methodology and that we achieve the same success.

Fiscal if we do not want to give up the fight against tax havens and even if we want a more determined contribution from banks and financial services to work effectively.

Thank you, Madam President. We are discussing today another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of the Syrian activist Aytan Al-Maleh, an eighty-year-old man, lawyer, accused of spreading false and exaggerated news that weakens the national feelings of his country.

In addition to the violation of the rights of countless treaties and international conventions, the imprisonment of this man, defender of human rights, is even contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction over civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken.

Pelas autoridades sírias são práticas que entram em contradição com o importante papel da Síria em toda a região e não refletem os esforços que têm sido feitos neste país para melhorar a situação social.
I repeat, we are discussing today another situation of human rights violations.
It is not possible to separate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two: the first, the overturning of the death sentence for strangulation imposed on Sakineh Rostinnejadi.
Many voices have joined and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to sing victories, but it is much less time to be silent. On the second, we approved today an important resolution against the abuses imposed by the government of Sarkozy on Greek and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights has no borders and is not a fight that can be stopped only outside.
Today we give a good example of how to lock it also inside doors.
The unjustified arrest of Daitarn Almalek unites us all here today.
He is a defender of human rights.
Human rights defenders have to be free people and that is what we demand from the Syrian authorities.
We, also human rights defenders, will not leave him alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the fact that there is a growing tendency for the safety profile of new medicines to only be fully known after they enter the market imposes the need for a more effective pharmacovigilance system than the one we have so far.
We are facing a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level, let's make it closer to the citizens now.
The new medicines have played a fundamental role in public health and in the advances in health care over the last few decades.
Adverse drug reactions remain the fifth leading cause of hospital death.
The proposals presented strengthen the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community system of pharmacovigilance, improving coordination and transparency.
Its objective is monitoring, early detection, communication, and evaluation of adverse reactions.
The new drugs will have a graphic symbol that indicates they are still under review.

The participation of the user in the control is encouraged, studies on the effectiveness at the national level are encouraged, new sensitivity to environmental consequences is opened, and community control institutions are improved.
It is for this reason that I congratulate you, Mr. President, on the proposals.
I would like to thank the rapporteur and also the Commission, in the spirit of cooperation, as well as the Presidency of Spain.
E por isso, com as propostas apresentadas neste pacote legislativo, acolhendo com agrado o documento final que será votado amanhã. Obrigado Senhor Presidente, obrigado.
Mr. President, I would like to begin by thanking and congratulating the rapporteur, as well as all the colleagues who were involved in this process.

We know that the adverse effects of medications are the fifth leading cause of hospital death. It is never too much to repeat this, and a strong and transparent system of drug surveillance is essential.
We now have the opportunity to strengthen the safety of the medicines that are already available, going beyond laboratory tests that do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were necessary to justify the importance of a new system, see what happened with the flu vaccine H1N1, speed in placing the vaccine on the market and neglect in investigating the side effects that have been detected and that are still delaying a complete investigation.
That is why it is necessary to continue to deepen this path.
This directive ensures the most active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
In fact, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive sum game.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and low-density population areas have their own very difficult challenges that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the peoples.
But we have to go beyond the declarations of intentions, otherwise we have the opposite effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are enormous reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green zones provide an essential service to all, yet they suffer from the consequent limitations to their economy.
Há que retribuir.
The populations of these regions must be solidarily supported by all.
I leave you the proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and development.
Many of these regions are authentic outdoor laboratories, given their richness, but they do not have equal access to research resources.
Why not then endow them with centers of excellence research, generating quality employment and dynamizing their economies?
A segunda proposta tem a ver com a energia.
These regions can and should be the embryo of projects that show the potential of self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, namely through the micro generation of local sources.
Reduced dependence, increased equality and job creation.
Finally, I would like to point out that using GDP as the sole or main indicator for the allocation of funds to aid can only lead to more injustice.
Therefore, it is very important to use complementary data, especially those that reflect the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make a special reference here to the peoples of the Azores, the Madeira, the mountainous areas and the depopulated interior areas of Portugal.
With your effort, much contributes to the development and quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all regions have their context.
Social, economic and territorial cohesion should not be seen as a charity service.
It is here that it is defined whether we want or not a true European redistribution policy.
I consider, for all this, this resolution as very important, but first step. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, materializes the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities that exist between the various regions.
It is not enough, however, to express in the text of the Treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions in the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

Therefore, it is necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and realistically overcome the delay of these regions by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potentialities and resources and contribute to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.
This incentive to these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the cohesion fund and the four structural funds.
Also, a different use of the various sectoral policies that have a relevant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we must maintain GDP as the main indicator of eligibility.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it is appropriate to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete portrait of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Remember the case of the peripheral regions, whose status is recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The regions of the outermost periphery, united due to their particular characteristics, also differ in their levels of development.

Also in relation to these, complementary indicators of the GDP should be used, capable of providing a more complete description of its specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of its level of development. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I greet this motion for a resolution that calls for the need for the existence of a European strategy that makes it possible to translate the principle of cohesion.
Territorial gain with the Treaty of Lisbon in opportunities for the populations of territories that suffer from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints accumulate and intensify, as in other regions called peripheral regions of Europe, according to Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
In the wake of the Commission's communication, the multi-stakeholder meetings, a turning point for Europe in 2008, and after the extended debate in which the RUPs themselves participated.
We actively hope for our version of this strategy, which will have to take into account not only our constraints, but above all our potentialities.
I appeal to the Commission to be sober in its presentation so that we can establish the best strategy before the debate on new perspectives.

Financial resources, because we must first define the content of the policies before allocating the necessary means for their implementation, as has been the case with the community policies now under review.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues. After four consecutive years of reducing the unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has nullified many of the progress made.
The unemployment rates in the European Union have increased enormously, for example, in Portugal we reached the record value, unfortunately, of an unemployment rate of eleven.
Another negative phenomenon is the high youth unemployment rate in the European Union.
Europe is thus going through a period of transformation and faces enormous challenges.
The crisis nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the fragility of the economies of its member states and, consequently, the European Union itself.
The 2020 strategy outlines the paths to follow.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts in the direction of promoting employment and social inclusion as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposal for a resolution on the future of the Social Fund, which is currently under debate, is greeted, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 strategy.

In fact, this fund is the main financial instrument that allows the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the levels of education and qualification of its citizens.
The FSE must be strengthened as the main engine of the 2020 strategy and must be used by Member States to invest in qualification, employment, training and professional reconversion.
Finally, I would like to point out that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out together with the other structural funds, should facilitate and simplify its management.
Reinforce transparency, as well as concentrate funds on achieving results and achieving objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is probably the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
Therefore, it must have a great articulation with the regional development fund.
It is essential to adopt a local approach to the issues to be resolved, that is, a global vision for local action.

Local and regional authorities are the most knowledgeable entities about their realities, their investment needs, job creation, and the most appropriate measures for promoting employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an outer region where unemployment usually reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

And this is largely due to the prospective planning strategy used for employment, defining factors that act on how to achieve the desired Vox Sur and also the use of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training, and promotion of employment.
The horizontality of the cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the strategy.
The cohesion policy is the great pillar of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the European Union as a whole is encouraged.
In the next period, 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of reinforcing the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels must be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Lisbon Treaty.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very important challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the application of European policies.
The GDP must continue to be the main criterion of eligibility, but we must take into account other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of the regional reality.
The population is aging and has very low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union, to which we must give concrete answers.
This observation has been consensual during this debate between us, despite the different views that this discussion has been highlighting.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it occurs in the majority of the Member States of the European Union.
I am sure that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave can help reverse these trends.
We must send to families a message of support for motherhood with concrete measures for a better reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the job market.
The achievement of this challenge is essential if we want to achieve the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already paid at one hundred percent for one hundred and twenty days, in an attempt to counteract the low birth rate we suffer.
I therefore defend that women's salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave, as presented in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State to create conditions that ensure the objective of full payment of maternity leave by 2020 seems a sensible procedure.
Finally, I greet the rapporteur, Rita Estrela, for her persistence in defending the measures aimed at protecting families, while also contributing to countering population growth.

I first, regarding these two reports, would like to greet and give here public testimony that I have already given in the Constitutional Affairs Committee of the remarkable work that the two of you did.
Colleagues Lena Swooboda, Ror Berent, Diana Wallis and Rebecca Arms, who were part of the Parliament deputies' team that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

Lisboa e o primeiro framework agreement, que tem uma base direta, uma base expressa NOS Tratados, mais precisamente no artigo 295 do Tratado sobre o Funcionamento da União Europeia.

Parliament and the Commission and represents essentially a commitment, a balance between the vision of the two institutions on the new role that each of them has after the Lisbon Treaty.

I believe that the work of our negotiation team was, in fact, very positive, because it was possible to give a translation in this framework agreement to those that are the new competences and to that which is the reinforcement of powers that results from the Lisbon Treaty.
This applies to the legislative process and to programming or planning, namely, for example, just to give two examples of Parliament's involvement in the
The Commission's work program or, for example, on issues related to the use of software in those that are legislative competencies of the Parliament by the Commission.

In a second line, a very important aspect is the strengthening of the powers of control and scrutiny of the Parliament, both in terms of detailing and specifying the rules of election of the President and the body of Commissioners, for example.

Regarding the presence of the Parliament in the own in issues such as the amendment or with the eventual removal of a Commissioner or, for example, the hearing of the directors of the regulatory agencies or, well, the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was, in fact, a consecration of powers that are powers that result from the Treaty of Lisbon.
Very important is also access to information and in particular access to that which is classified information or that which is information.
Confidential and, moreover, the exchange of information and the exchange of points of view between the Parliament's responsible and the Commission's responsible.

For example, we know that today it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for social affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

Or, for example, that there are several platforms for dialogue between the Commission, the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Presidents of the Commissions, the President of the Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of them expressed.
Even the presence of the Commission in Parliament was reinforced, namely through the application of the question hour not only to the Commission President, but also to the Commissioners.
I would say, therefore, that I have a deep respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and a deep respect for the idea of separation of powers.
We have here a clarifying agreement that will make the Lisbon Treaty current, alive, and applicable.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur colleague on her work, as well as greeting all those who collaborated with her on this report, which made it possible to obtain this agreement in the first reading.

The current directive, which reformulates the previous directive by more than ten years, aims, as has been recognized by all, to put an end to a widespread problem in the European Union of payment delays.
Behind these, which in some Member States are unjustifiably long when they involve public administration.

The negative effects of this practice in economic life are enormous, whether at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises, at the level of the internal market, and these negative effects cannot be tolerated any more, especially since we are living in an economic and financial crisis, like the one we are going through.
This legislative amendment comes to give coherence and to give meaning to the plan for the relaunch of the European economy and the application of the small.
Business act. Surely this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.
The creditors will have an effective and efficient instrument to exercise their rights against the defaulting debtors.
With this directive, the censurable practice of public entities will be an exception.
Public administration bodies must set an example of good people and pay bills for goods and services within a month.
Now it will be up to the institutions involved, the Council and the Member States, to allow the transposition of this directive to be done as quickly as possible. Thank you.
Thank you. There is a great disparity in many Member States regarding the payment conditions for companies, especially when the state is involved, such as in the case of large companies.

We who have seen companies know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased financing difficulties, companies are increasingly debating liquidity problems, even in many Member States exposed to an increased risk of bankruptcy.
It seems clear that the current directive that tried to regulate this matter had limited effects, so the proposal that we are now analyzing represents an important step in compliance.
Os prazos de pagamento não só nas relações entre as empresas e as entidades públicas, como também e ISTO é essencial nas relações que as empresas estabelecem entre si.

We now have a legislation that brings us a greater added value with a clear system of sanctions for payment delays and that also brings us an effective improvement in the balance of the abuse of the dominant position that the state and large companies establish.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, allow me to speak about the unsaid.

I listened very carefully, Commissioner, and from what I heard, it seems to me to say, it seems to me to say that, so far, it seems that the most effective act, whether by national authorities or by European authorities, was the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided. This is also why there is European legislation and it seems obvious that the law was violated.
There was inefficiency, late response, abandonment of affected people, and, in particular, the most disadvantaged.
People have died and many are still today under the threat of what can happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs and it is immoral not to take care of the victims.
How is it possible? I ask you, Madam Commissioner, that we know news through reports that come to us from Hungarian citizens and citizens, and the authorities see nothing or tell us nothing.
That is why I would like to raise some questions.
How is it that the bank pressures citizens with a mortgaged house in the affected area, asking them to pay what they owe, since their houses have lost value?

It is that, in this way, it seems that we are always starting from scratch.
