Public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions. On the contrary, it must be analyzed with the utmost priority.
We know well what happened with the flu and this should serve as a lesson for all of us.
And I don't know if you remember well how all this started, but the truth is that it started in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the size of the problem.
That is why the report that was voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole story went and who decided to pay for it if it had happened like that.
Como temos direito de saber quais foram os países que responderam de determinada forma, porque é que responderam sem transparência e sem que NOS deixassem ficar?
The minimum of doubts, because we maintain all the doubts, if there was or was not a deal, we have to have the guarantee that no trace remains if there was or was not a deal related to this flu.
And that is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be faced, but it is not different the way they are faced, nor who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we are here to talk about proposals on salaries and proposals on the retirement age and the minimum we can say in relation to these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
They are unfair and insist on recipes that have already been proven to be failed more than once.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and do you know how many other countries? Because this is an endless succession, there are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some things in common.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of the value of work to financial capital.
We cannot accept this.
The other thing we have in common is that those who are paying for this crisis are the workers, the pensioners, and a whole generation of precarious workers.
"Não tem qualquer garantia nesta sociedade em que vivemos e é por isso que gostaria de terminar dizendo, senhor presidente e senhor comissário, não podemos continuar a condenar as pessoas à pobreza."
I hope sincerely.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to start by saying that I fully support what my colleague said.
The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous and growing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of intentions, procedures, and schedules.
But there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.
The solidarity fund is an instrument that normally responds to these situations, but it responds in a very, very long time, nine months to a year, and this after the catastrophe.

As has already been mentioned, and I repeat, and we will repeat to the end, the time that is necessary for the case of Madeira, a year ago there was a huge catastrophe, and it has not yet received any support.
And I ask, therefore, and I reinforce this question, will the Commission not be in a position to review the procedure of the Fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exception fund to deal with situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen and the climate changes are there to prove it.
Therefore, exception cannot ever respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding prevention and response to disasters are matters of great sensitivity and utmost importance to our populations, which should not be trivialized.

We talk about very sensitive situations that affect the safety of people and their property, which often move everyone by the loss of lives, destroyed families, and the devastation of entire working lives.

But little do all our manifestations matter in the face of the dramas that, in a media way, impress and sensitize everyone. If we then fall asleep about the work we must do to prevent, minimize, or better, assist those situations.
Mr. Commissioner, the article here is very well focused by my colleagues.

It is a subject where the European Union can better demonstrate its presence alongside its citizens, helping them in the prevention of catastrophes, especially when they occur and being by their side in the moments they need and are most vulnerable.
I will respond with all my heart, although I do not want to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a debate on Portuguese politics.

By the way, if Deputy Rita Estrada wants to debate Portuguese politics, she has a simple solution: we should have elections, candidates for the Portuguese parliament, and she will have the opportunity in opposition to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I am just saying the following, we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times in two years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible for the markets, there are no more solutions than the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by thanking my colleague Schwab for his negotiating persistence, which led to this important commitment, and I also greet all those who collaborated with him in this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, whatever their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the twenty-seven Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.
This new directive will end the legislative fragmentation that has been harming the participation of our companies in the transborder market and will give a significant boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions regarding the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, intelligible and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements falls on the trader.

Regarding contracts concluded at a distance, especially contracts concluded by telephone or by internet, their rules must be defined and the consumer must be protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council and Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24-25 March, namely for the consolidation of the semester.

European, but much more than that, be it for the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, be it for the purpose, let's say, of the Euro Plus Pact, which was already coming from the eurozone summit of March 11th.
I believe that these are very positive results for Europe and it is a shame that this process has not been completely concluded on March 24-25.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the states had given that signal in the Council, by completely closing this package of fundamental reform, we would be in a position today.

The most important thing is to face the three or four months and in part we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing and on which I also do not want to leave a word.

To say that, in the case of PSD, fully integrated into PPE, there is an absolute and total availability for compliance with those that are the requirements and obligations of integration into the European space.
This is what we have done even now, at this moment when there are difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike the socialist government, the Social Democratic Party has shown total willingness to give the guarantees to Europe that are necessary in the context of this crisis.

E com ISTO quero dar este sinal sem trazer a política interna para o Parlamento Europeu do compromisso, da total garantia do Partido Social Democrata na rigorosa agenda que o país vai ter de ter depois das suas eleições de 5 de junho.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fule, the historic moment we are living in calls for a firm and determined action.
As many of you, it is with a mixture of hope, concern, and expectation that we witness the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin.

I am, however, pleased with the pro-active position that the Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
From the outset, by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our values, our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer transgress in the defense of democracy, nor in the defense of human rights, and much less in the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the higher interests of citizens and their intransigent defense of their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union has to privilege an approach from the base to the top in its neighborhood policy.
It is essential that this happens.
Only the highest level of involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum efficiency in its implementation.

But I cannot fail to express frustration. I am sorry that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take advantage of this opportunity to differentiate once and for all the policy of the Eastern Neighbourhood with the countries that may potentially become in the future our partners in the Union of the Southern Neighbourhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its April 20 review process, the ambition that the current moment demands, a policy of neighborhood.
Tailor-made to each state, with clear benchmarks and careful evaluation that allows for a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the south.

To conclude, Commissioner, we trust that the good atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The reports that we are discussing and that the rapporteurs are presenting reinforce a set of initiatives aimed at the relaunch of the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Mr Barnier, whom I greet, and the positive reception of this Parliament.
The Commission for the Protection of the Consumer and the Internal Market to prioritize competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 strategy.
Citizens and companies are waiting for effective impulses for Europe to grow economically again. They are waiting for an increase in employment, they are aiming for the creation of more prosperity.

And as the Commissioner highlighted, the opening of markets to our companies, by eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will give a very special impetus and an unparalleled opportunity for them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

The measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden of PMEs and their access to credit and the service market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
The relevance of the development of electronic commerce to strengthen the trust of consumers and companies in this type of commerce, the focus on innovation.
Important for strong and sustainable growth, social entrepreneurship is essential for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening and fully exploiting the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation for Member States to redouble efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also want to join my voice with all those who have expressed concerns here about the low earnings of fishermen, worsened by the historical prices of fuel, especially in recent months.
As was very well said here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized boat owners, and are particularly worsening the already fragile earnings of fishing.
This steep rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects, such as reduced exports to the sea, and meager returns for fishermen, worsened by the low prices paid at the first sale.

Increases in the importation of third-country products of aquaculture and fishing to the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, with more job losses.
In this context, to prevent the crisis from worsening, it is necessary to act and act with solidarity and depth in the problems of fishing.

The Commission must therefore provide positive answers with short and long-term measures to address the challenges faced by the sector and the serious loss of income that our fishermen are experiencing.
Dear rapporteur, first of all, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our colleague from PPE, Mario David, who is here today to be absolutely.
I have always been unable to attend this plenary and I would like to say that we always considered that the support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan was an ethical and moral imperative.
And for this reason, we strongly support all the measures that have been taken in the direction of traditional humanitarian aid.
We consider that we must continue to work in the sense of helping to stabilize the situation of so many millions of people affected.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered as a proper and adequate instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two harmful consequences, one consequence within the European Union, especially for the southern countries and for its textile clothing industry, which is now highly weakened by an economic, social and financial crisis without parallel since the.

"Entrada na União e em segundo lugar, a nível global, nas negociações da OMC, onde esta abertura do maior bloco comercial do mundo, que é a União Europeia, a essas eventuais exportações paquistanesas pode desequilibrar por completo as negociações."
And it is not by chance that they find themselves in the deadlock in which they find themselves.

It is therefore natural that, in the face of such a situation, we have to say, with regard to the history of this regulation and the difficulty it has had in these eight months of intense negotiations,

Which proposals do we collaborate with the most constructive that we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position that will be a position in the sense of supporting the amendment that fundamentally foresees the end of this regulatory proposal, as we know it?
We will have to do it at this time, not least out of solidarity with Pakistan, but because we consider that humanitarian aid should be given in the place itself and in its own way.
Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, of course, I consider that the agreement that has been reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it puts its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I think that is very positive.

I do not take the attitude of others who consider that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything right, did not make mistakes, did not exaggerate, did everything right and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have made mistakes and had wrong policies, but that does not mean that there is not now an opportunity in the context of the Union to have here the possibility of returning to the right path and the right path.

And for this reason, it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell the public opinions that are against the support of countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
But they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are making a business that is positive for their budgets and their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it was time to have a European global response with the admission of eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of sale in the primary market to respond to international markets.

And it would perhaps be time for the European Commission, the Fund and the IMF to review the interest rates in order to give the possibility of lowering these rates, of having a sustained growth of these countries that are now in difficulties.

Thank you, I give the floor for one minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner and Madam Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially for those whose economy lacks competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, the most active job creation.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose relationship with the productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system that will have a new market in innovation as the traditional manufacturing model is exhausted.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, it will have to be served by new financial instruments so that it does not succumb to budgetary limitations of the current situation.
I would finally like to greet Judith Marquies for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe and an economy more based on knowledge. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to start by congratulating my colleague O'Di on his excellent report.

The intercalary assessment, although late, allowed to highlight the critical aspects of the seventh program, its excessive bureaucracy, the industry's disinterest, the number and complexity of the new instruments, and the weak pace of disbursements.
There is still a greater risk of diverted transfers of funds from the current program framework to large-scale programs and of questionable added value.

But it also allowed to highlight positive aspects, a greater articulation and international cooperation between scientific groups in common projects, some cases of success, among them the European Research Council and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that must be developed. First, simplification, second, promoting scientific excellence, not only in some countries, but throughout Europe, a greater connection.

The program quadro with innovation, with instruments aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to address the proposal that was presented to Parliament today and I would like to tell you frankly that I think that we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal that is presented is not only weak, but has immense gaps.
I think this is a European issue, not a question of states that have nuclear industry and those that do not. It is a question of the totality of Europe and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I honestly have to tell you that one of these good news is to ensure the citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are done in the terms in which the Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is done by the parties themselves, a second phase is done by the states.

Defendem esses interessados e uma terceira fase é feita pelos pares que estão verdadeiramente interessados. Eu pergunto-me se o resultado não será dizer, afinal, que todas as centrais nucleares estão de muito boa saúde e recomendam.

We know that this is not the case, and therefore I hope that there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending to do so. Thank you very much.
I hope this European Council, especially with the climate that is being experienced in recent weeks, will make a decision of great responsibility.
And more responsibility than that which existed in the last council, in which a problem was postponed for three months only because of electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision of responsibility will essentially be understood that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental to that which is the main purpose of Europe, which is the purpose of maintaining peace.
If an approach to the problems is made that only leads to states beginning to distrust each other, to installing distrust among the different states.
To create and fuel differences and rivalries between southern states and northern states, between central states and peripheral states. What we are being led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political disagreements, is whether we want the European project to continue as a valid project for the peace strategy in Europe.
I guess that's what is at stake.
A que noto em muitos discursos de líderes, tanto daqueles que estão em países em dificuldades como daqueles de países que são países pagadores.
The tax payers is an irresponsible speech that often appeals to some negative characteristics of nationalities.
I appeal to this and only this, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of the European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a solution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. My first words are to praise the work developed by the rapporteur, my colleague Georgios Stavrakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying the future synergies for enhanced effectiveness among the various structural funds.

Your report is also part of this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that takes on greater importance not only because of the substance of the issue, but also, and above all, because of the opportunity in terms of timing of your discussion.
As a result, we are currently in the process of understanding the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future cohesion policy after 2013.
The cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments of excellence, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, seeking to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
The experience, however, has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that result from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

From here, a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-focused approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for better efficiency in the application of resources.
We have to take advantage of the crisis to look for new alternatives.

And it is certain that all these reports that are here today for discussion will pose enormous challenges, and we know that in order to respond to these challenges, we also need a good budget. But we have to make a clear distinction between what are the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known and in fact, just by affirming these political objectives, we can offer a future to the regions.
And if so, we must then place the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space with an internal market, a common currency, requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions to function.
The current divergences in competitiveness, the asymmetries in development inevitably led to the weakening of the European space and the crisis that affects the eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a powerful budget for cohesion that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union to do more has to have more and this is achieved by growing its budget and not reducing, even if skillfully, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner if the creation of the fund for infrastructure and the new innovation policies that will be articulated with cohesion and regional development, which I support, cannot be transformed into the Trojan horse that was introduced in the cohesion budget without an increase in the community budget.

The modernization and renovation of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and intelligent growth objectives that we seek with the 2020 strategy and for our energy security that we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

For this, the incentives provided in regulatory systems must be improved, especially those applied to high-risk and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in renewable energies.

The regions should be associated with the phases of conception and implementation of projects in the definition of priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this guarantees better results and therefore a better defense of the European interest.
The current economic moment accentuates even more the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is essential not to lose sight of its effects in the medium and long term, seeking to ensure all European citizens with a safe, sustainable, and affordable energy.

The report we are discussing is of particular importance, taking into account the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

The collaboration with the rapporteur was very productive and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself said, allowing for the adoption of several commitments in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.
For the result that we have here today, that we are debating, I congratulate the rapporteur.
In fact, on our part, the main concern was to make it clear that the competences in this matter belong to the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the powers to define, organize and finance social services of general interest.

Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given that the realities of these social services of general interest are very diverse in the twenty-seven Member States.

Just pay attention to the health, social security, employment, and social housing services, which are examples of how proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fair provision of these services. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. Alves, Mr. President, as rapporteur of the opinion of the REGI on the future of social services of general interest, I would like to congratulate my colleague de Rossa, underlining the fact that we are facing an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we defend for Europe and in which the SIEG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

The social cohesion at the level of the European Union advises not to neglect the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States, without prejudice to the respect for the competences of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions have a very important role in the provision of these services to the populations and their opinion should be taken into account, given the nature of their constraints to ensure the provision of these services to the populations.

At a time of crisis, such as the one we are currently experiencing, social services of general interest constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is therefore important to ensure that Member States that decentralize powers are accompanied by the respective financial means so that regional and local authorities can ensure their good performance to the populations.
Senhor Ashton, I begin by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time and that's why I just want to leave some notes.
First of all, we cannot forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not a civil war, have to be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious. This applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to interfere in their internal affairs and, above all, and especially, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
E se digo ISTO, digo-o porque devemos repudiar totalmente o que se está a passar na Líbia.
The NATO and the United Nations have exceeded all resolutions, even those that were voted on by the United Nations Security Council.
And it is this silence regarding Libya, this repulsion that we must make, and it is because it does not exist in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Polish Presidency for the ambitious program that it has brought here, and in particular, I would like to congratulate it for the

Neighbourhood policy not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I believe that at this moment a challenge is being faced, perhaps more demanding than the one we have in the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, the economic government, and the supervision of financial markets.
I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals may be in the areas of defense, energy, food security, environment, agriculture, and multiyear financial frameworks, if we do not.

If we do not resolve the problem of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid way in the face of the global markets, we will not have a Europe strong enough to deal with these challenges that the Polish presidency proposed.

And that is why I was calling attention to the fact that it is essential to convince the remaining heads of state and government that it is necessary to give more economic integration, more economic government to the European Union.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the leaders or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, in Parliament, or in the European Interests Commission, instead of being that, we will only be the public.
Thank you, Mr. President. As the president of the Mashreq delegation, I would like to leave a sentence about each of my four countries in quotation marks.
Starting with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have already said, I regret that the international community appears to the public opinion to have two weights and two measures.

It is necessary to denounce, if necessary, the countries that in the Security Council and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, and in short, in addition to Brazil, but with veto power, which has prevented the international community from taking a more consistent position with what should be the values that we share.
Regarding Egypt, I believe there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities for the postponement of the elections, as was done in Tunisia.
Regarding Lebanon, I believe that this debate should result in a very clear message for the new Lebanese government.
To make them aware that they will be judged based on their actions regarding the accusations made by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

About Jordan is an example that a peaceful transition is possible and that there is perhaps only a need in this phase to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
Não podemos esquecer, obviamente, num debate deste género, o processo de paz no Médio Oriente e reiterar a nossa esperança de que a reunião do Quarteto da próxima segunda-feira possa.
To be effective and to reaffirm that this House would surely like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union in this whole process.
I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the UN General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and done in good faith.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report will constitute a reference in terms of recommendations and solid, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If there is a conclusion that can be drawn, it is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be surpassed with the deepening of European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic, and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as in my country, Portugal, it is tempting to take refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But this is a mistake.

The European response to the crisis requires a true European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term answers with defined objectives with which Member States identify.
The exit strategy from the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avoid a new sovereign debt crisis and the euro, a tighter coordination in budgetary policies is necessary, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt and euro bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that, in this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain the levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the Presidency in office, it is often said that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, it was like this, but today I am not so sure that this is still true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis aggravates the situation every day and exacerbates the dismay and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening manner.
This, despite the problems of the eurozone resulting from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today focus on its most fragile aspects.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as was the case in the past, and unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to imprint on the European program and project.
This report from the Parliament gives us, however, this view: more Europe, and not less, is the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the single market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and that they must be countered by specific policies.
Recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget through own resources, requires a European debt issuance agency capable of protecting states from market speculation.

And provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament united to send clear messages. Let us hope that the Commission and the Council will listen to them.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleague rapporteur. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for considering that this report is extremely useful and allows us to take new steps in the area of mediation.
O relatório apresenta uma panorâmica, um leque das soluções adotadas pelos vários Estados-Membros na concretização, na aplicação das.
The directive 2008/52/CE of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, concerning the mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now we all know the advantages of mediation.
Por um lado, é uma extrajudicial de resolução dos conflitos, contribui para o descongestionamento dos tribunais, para a racionalização do sistema de justiça, proporcionando ao mesmo tempo.
Simultaneously providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster and less costly solution, less onerous than the litigation in which they are engaged.

That is why it is crucial to reaffirm the objective of the first article of the directive, which calls for the adoption of measures of incentive to resort to the means of alternative dispute resolution, and in particular, to mediation.
Promoting access and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

This is why it is a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the space of freedom, security and justice. I would say for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
E é por isso que, neste contexto também de crise, considero muito importante que, conforme se diz no relatório, se possa sensibilizar a opinião pública, os operadores.

Constitutional. My colleague Nesser Schmidt, a Danishman, is absent because he is running for election in Denmark at the moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member of the AFCO, but also as a member of the jury as a shadow rapporteur in the jury of this report.

The first question I wanted to say is that in the crisis in which we are in the economic and financial crisis, the question of intelligent regulation of smart regulation of better legislation is a central question.

There is no doubt that in the so-called structural reforms that can make the economic and financial start of the European space, also the improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe that aims to be dynamic and competitive must have simple and accessible regulation for companies and also, obviously, for citizens, and therefore, must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first of all, the program of reduction of administrative burdens be implemented, and that all efforts be made in this direction.

Promover consultas aos agentes do mercado, às associações representativas de cidadãos e de empresas e que se faça a avaliação de impacto da própria legislação. Isso é também extremamente importante de forma a.

A processo de decisão possa essencialmente ter, digamos, como base justamente a opinião daqueles que são destinatários da legislação e que possa ser feito sem encargos administrativos e com menos custos económicos e financeiros.

It is important to say that for the Commission on Constitutional Affairs, in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant. This idea that European intervention should be an adequate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexity of the system.

Legal and regulatory system and therefore we pay special attention, in our opinion, to the reinforced role that national parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, at the level of smart regulation and at the level of legislation improvement, we now involve national parliaments so that both legislation and regulation are at the European level, at the national level.
Be more agile, smarter, more efficient, and therefore, this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive and agile Europe through smarter regulation.
Madam President, the number of people without shelter, as well as those living below the poverty line, has not stopped increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have aggravated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We all agree that this phenomenon is the negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.

In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong, strong measure of austerity, the concept of homelessness, according to the national plan, includes people who will ask for help to take a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than twenty percent since two thousand and eight.
Note a greater increase in families and people in need who have seen their altered life situation due to unemployment and also to bank indebtedness.
This is just an example that demonstrates the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration on a strategy of the European Union for the homeless.

With this statement, this parliament has alerted to the need for the European Union to adopt a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term objective of ending the situations of people who sleep on the street and the state of long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of Member States.
We took good note of the words of the Commissioner and recorded the point of the situation that he made to us.

I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong impetus to coordinate the action of Member States and regional authorities in the fight against this social injustice. Thank you very much.
We are debating the peace process in the Middle East, but is there any process in progress that I have missed?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly pronounces itself, like the majority of the international community, for the existence of two peoples and two states sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea, which have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.

But without dialogue between the parties, in which, by being immersed in a whirlwind of hatred and misunderstandings that has been going on for sixty-three years, only extremisms and frustrations are fed.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League become much more involved in the search for a negotiated solution to the borders, based on the existing ones in 1967, with the exchanges that allow most of the Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

That the issue of Jerusalem, holy city, future capital of the two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that it is the land of milk and honey.

All countries should participate in the resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue and the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, should participate in the necessary financial compensations.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be put in place as a guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
Thus, there must be courage and political will.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, tourism needs a clear and coordinated European approach, with a careful look at the potential and challenges that the different tourism modes have to offer us.
The tourism diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and the competitiveness of the European Union itself.

A bet in this key sector, which accounts for ten percent of GDP and about twelve percent of employment in the European Union, will not only create added European value, but also address the economic crisis in which we find ourselves.
I come from an outer region of Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

And therefore, the creation of a specific section for the sector in the 2014-2020 financial framework is essential for the solid and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a true European tourism policy, sustainable and diversified, requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined calendar, actions and financing, capable of reinforcing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The non-existence of a peace process in progress is calling into question basic rights and has led to the assumption of unilateral measures by each party that are not.

Contribui de forma alguma para um desanuviar das tensões na região e muito menos para a busca efetiva de uma vida para os dois povos que têm o direito a viver harmoniosamente em paz, segurança e com dignidade.

It is time for the international community to say enough. It is time for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution with sensibility, presenting viable solutions without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let's start with Jerusalem, why not recover the initial idea of a corpus separatum administered by the UN and that obviously functions as the capital of the two states?
Borders. Let's start with the sixty-seven.
Exchange land parcels whenever possible and consistent.
Take care of the defense of Israel, a matter obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people, for example, through the placement of blue helmets with American, European and Islamic forces next to Jordan.
Refugees, there are about four point eight million and have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a land, preferably their own.

But it is not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem, it is also ours, of the Arab neighboring countries, of the Arab world in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
The colonels have to end their expansion, and this is not negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and translates hypocrisy and bad faith in an announcement of availability for immediate negotiations.

Above all, we want good faith negotiations committed to a deadline for their conclusion, from which the international community, in order to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt another attitude.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. The shameful situation that exists in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned. We all share in it, and I share in it very much what my colleagues have just said.
I will not refer to this in particular, I refer to another situation that is more omitted, which is that of the citizens who were received in the homes of families in Tunisia.

And this is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because let us compare Tunisia in a crisis situation to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transition to democracy and did not know how to be supportive, did not receive.
I think it is indeed shameful that we can count as a few hundred the number of refugees that have arrived in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what was said, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the level of infrastructure, has implications at the level of what is called the harvest in these countries.
And it is for this reason, Madam Commissioner, that I am very aware of the appeal you make and I do not say it ironically, I say it seriously, but please, what about the Commission?
E a Europa?
What can you do?
How is it that Europe lives so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
Não pode continuar.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all the Members of the European Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.

And having said that, I would like to say that we now expect from the Commission a very, very determined action together with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know that it is a marathon, but immediate signals are needed.

And therefore, without prejudice to the fact that we have all already begun to think of a change in the Treaties that gives political translation to the whole project that we have brought here today, without prejudice to this, something must be done now.

This set of measures and, perhaps, an agreement, an agreement between states, what I have called a kind of para-social agreement that goes beyond treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Many congratulations for your courage and determination.
I believe that we are on the right track and that we will leave here today with another.

During the crisis that the European Union is going through, there have been serious consequences in all the member states and there are thousands of workers affected by the layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.

We cannot fail to affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to affirm that Europe must help the Member States to maintain a high employment rate and to combat unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has accessed it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this fund for adjustment to globalization, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through measures of professional training, help in the creation of companies, and incentives for recruitment.

This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this fund to support workers who have been laid off as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the most affected Member States should have greater access and easier access to this support fund for globalization and the crisis.
Thank you, Mr. President. I greet the Polish Presidency and also Commissioner Alun Michael David. I just want to say that I consider that.
And today, in the sequence and development of what was done in the State of the Union address, a very, very big step was taken to be able to solve the problems of the crisis of the eurozone.
Because the Commission has taken on its commitment here to use its power of initiative and to use it together with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe that this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at this moment to solve the crisis of the eurozone.
There is no possibility of resolving it in the short term only as an intergovernmental approach and therefore it is necessary that the states, the governments of the states, give.
Commission the instruments and mandate for it to lead this resolution process, for it to put into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that it presented here.
But I did not want to leave out that this is not incompatible with what we do at the same time, with what we develop at the same time, our ability to alter the treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term, it is necessary to change the treaties, but we will also have to do it in the sense of strengthening, in the sense of giving more strength and greater position to the Commission.

It is through the reinforcement of the Community method now in the short term and then with a change of the Treaties in the long term that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the seventeen countries of the eurozone and for the twenty-seven countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce as one of the measures that banks that do not have capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and, if they cannot present them, must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not fail to agree with this presentation made by the President.
This week we saw what happened to Dexia Bank and a few months ago, a manager of this bank received a six hundred thousand euro prize for his wonderful management, as we know.
But to be serious, the commission president has to go to the governments and present the complete package, and the complete package is what is essential.
The essential thing is that the money from taxpayers has as a counterpart a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, including my country, Portugal.
In two years, better saying in three years, it is the second time that they ask us to save the banks with the money of the unemployed taxpayers.
The banks that also save the economy by helping to create jobs. Thank you very much.
Madam High Representative, there are times when I think that I do little and make balances, and this seems to be one of those times.
And it seems to me to be because we always go in the cadence of events and the response of event to event and we lose a little what is the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case and each country that we are talking about here is a specific case, but I forgive myself for saying, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize what criteria the European Union has used to act in each of the cases.
I fear that we are often hostages to the interests of the countries of the European Union, by some of these countries of the European Union and not by all.
And that is why we use so many times in this House the expression two weights and two measures, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions, yes, but it is not sanctions. Sometimes the interference goes to the limit of the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times it is total silence, as was the case in the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of the United States.

Saudi Arabia and Baroness, let me tell you, I have carefully studied all the dossiers. I have not yet seen a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the Saudi Arabian military forces.

Death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses who are sentenced to up to thirty years in prison by a military court for allegedly being against the regime and not helping the wounded they needed.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the regime of Saleh, we have had much more silence than actions.

I am not in favor of interference, I never was, but I fear that we will be placed in an uncomfortable position. The position from which we are being judged, Mrs. Barroso, is one of hindering development and aspirations.

Democráticas e revolucionárias dos povos dos países árabes, em vez de ajudarmos a primeira árabe, o que fazemos é impedir-nos que ela se estenda quer por excesso, quer por defeito, e não acho que devemos ficar com esse pecado.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to an activist Yemite can serve as a signal that our side is on the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner. This is a good report from colleague Casa.
First of all, we must ask why review the VAT in the European Union?
First, there is a need to make it compatible with the single market.
The more regimes and varieties of VAT, the less fluid the market will be.
A reform of the VAT favors e-commerce, focuses on competition in the value of goods and price, based on goods and services, and not on tax differences.
Combating fraud and ensuring the necessary trust, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other supporting measures are already in progress in the single market that can be associated with the IVV?
First, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, the single market measure seven.
The measure five on services, the need to review the legislation on normalization and implementation of the directive.
The measure 9, which aims to remove tax obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two fundamental orders of reasons.
First, the economic crisis.
More revenues are needed, including, probably in some countries, the reduction of contributions on labor to promote economic development, passing this task to the IVA.

Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, which, due to the reduction of the population base of incidence.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we have to reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization in these reforms.
It is necessary to narrow the range of variation in the normal VAT rate so that we can all better understand.
It is necessary greater transparency in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its field of application, a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for PMEs, knowing well that each exemption carries with it a court of small or large frauds.
Finally, to greet the recent proposal of the Commission to create a European VAT.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to thank my colleague Rüle for the excellent report he prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States undermine competitiveness.
The dichotomy, the quality of prices, and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is essential to look at the good existing practices, especially in Portugal, where electronic contracting has worked well and facilitated public contracting.
A European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficit and more growth.
And it should, for this, have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs and defend social and environmental values.

This is why I express satisfaction with the intentions that Commissioner Barnier presents to us here for the review of public procurement, as still this year, as one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
To congratulate colleague Rula and all who collaborated with her.
Important in the field of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.

That, unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union, fifty percent of the awards by electronic procedure in two thousand and ten failed, finding themselves in scarce average values of five percent.
Only a few countries, like my Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of public electronic contracting are very evident and were stated here. It allows the expensive access processes to be replaced by a simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it greatly reduces costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
A.

E mais fácil e flexível simplifica o acesso aos contratos públicos da União Europeia, especialmente para as pequenas e médias empresas, facilitando deste modo a participação no mercado dos contratos públicos destes importantes motores da economia.

In this regard, we greet and encourage the European Commission for the strengthening of mechanisms in the sense of transforming public electronic contracting into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe and if the situation quickly passed before the eyes of all from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of great European dimension, the truth is that the inadequacy of the solutions proposed and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid degradation of the situation.
The search for solutions aimed at states at the expense of truly European solutions allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts, imposing deadlines and rates.
Absolutely impossible goals that some states are trying to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable, applied to people, companies and the public sector.
It is absolutely essential to find a common solution to the risk of excessive European debts, which removes market pressure and speculation and provides time for the necessary adjustments to be made.
Without it, what we will have in the end will be countries that will continue without means to pay the creditors, destroyed economies and a lot, a lot of suffering.

To the shadow rapporteurs with whom I had a fruitful collaboration and I also thank the rapporteurs of the opinions of the four committees involved. These opinions are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received four hundred amendments and drafted forty-seven commitments that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest aroused by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is about preparing the human resources of Europe, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for preparing the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the coherence of the report.
I think this objective has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis that currently affects us has revealed the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the progress made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than five million jobs.
Today there are almost twenty three million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is close to twenty-one percent and represents more than twice the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary with levels of qualifications.
This means that people with higher qualifications find a job more easily.
We also know that in the near future, the needs in terms of skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, the creation of jobs, second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
After the sustainability of social security systems and finally the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job vacancies.

This report has a dual objective. First, to emphasize the need to act quickly in the sense of filling the gaps in skills in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

To this end, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of qualified labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, as well as foreign languages.
As I mentioned, the skills requirements must be identified early, within a horizon of at least ten years.
Today, the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications are known.
Afterwards, participation in lifelong learning and professional requalification, as well as the reduction of school dropout rates, must be increased.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of advancing with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that must exist between educational institutions and the needs of the job market.
The internships must be of quality and supervised by tutors in order to lead to a job and to end any potential abuses of the internship situation.
It also gives particular emphasis to the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job search and creation.
We have a future ahead and we have to create jobs.
E as pequenas e médias empresas jogam aqui um papel decisivo para esse objetivo.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, from there, the need for the coordination of social security systems so that workers can see their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility to improve the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexicurity must be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to start by thanking all the colleagues who have spoken in this live debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

By the way, this discussion is taking place on the eve of the European Council, which will show whether there is or not a political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is a will.

Política para um aprofundamento da nossa coordenação em termos económicos e se há realmente uma vontade harmonizada e unitária para conseguirmos levar por diante a ambição que está nesta agenda, ou seja, ter.

Novos empregos no próximo decênio novos empregos que levem a que os jovens que Hoje estão desempregados e àqueles que se estão a formar tenham esperança no mercado de trabalho tenham esperança no mercado de trabalho inclusivo que lhes dê resposta à sua.

Ambição de dignificação através do trabalho e que tenham também a oportunidade de estarem num dinamismo permanente para acompanhar os desafios de uma economia globalizada e com uma dinâmica que não tem paralelo nas últimas gerações.

Por isso, a nossa ambição é realmente que haja criação de empregos, que haja crescimento económico para não só dar resposta àqueles que estão desempregados na sequência da crise, como àqueles que vão entrar no mercado de trabalho e também dar.

Response to the great challenges that are there with the green economy, with services in the health area, with services in the transport and accommodation area, which require from all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you all very much.

Marisa Matias Thank you very much, Madam President. As we were told today in the Council's statement, it is that for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in the European Semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue, and the question I am asking is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where is the European Parliament's scrutiny?
Where is the scrutiny of national parliaments over their major budgetary options?

But if the issue were technical, as it was said here, then we are talking about a variable technique, because we know how the Council substantially alleviated the conditions of the four countries that are on the waiting list France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. The same did not happen in relation to the countries that are under rescue.
Therefore, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to have opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to have opinions about Germany?
And, Commissioner, please, I only ask you to pay attention to this. No problem of democratic legitimacy is solved by asking the deputies to consult the information on the internet.
This is a problem of underrepresentation, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is what we are talking about here. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. A first word to congratulate the rapporteur Darden for the quality and opportunity of this report, and also Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is really a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stem the increase of the phenomenon, which at the moment affects more than eighty million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already going through has made this situation worse and made the times we live in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of people unemployed does not stop increasing and we all know that unemployment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, willpower, and a lot of commitment from the European Commission and Member States.
If this does not happen, the objective of lifting twenty million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the platform against poverty, which is a very important instrument to ensure social justice.
But no one has any doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are the creation of jobs and the promotion of economic growth.
The access to the internet should be considered today as a new fundamental right of citizens and not only as a mere object of commerce, because of this right.
They also depend on essential things such as freedom of expression, access and sharing of information, access and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And it is for this reason that this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that place the free choice and the possibility of changing suppliers easily, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship demands, therefore, that complete and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of the free use of the internet is not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their people.
It can also happen that economic options result in the offering of privileges to special clients and a less equal treatment to clients who are not as profitable.
It is for this reason that I support the Parliament in clearly positioning itself alongside the neutrality of the Internet and the defense of its total character.
Let's be honest.
We have been taking the medication to get out of the crisis for three years and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we create two fatal vicious circles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, it is more easily discussed today the bankruptcy of a state than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks finance states and that states save their banks.
This spiral has to be broken.
The Commission must advance with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of states from the attacks of speculators.

And for this it is urgent and it is already late to prepare the coordinated sovereign debt emissions. Call them eurobonds or stability bonds and guarantee them through robust instruments of a community and not intergovernmental nature.
In short, we must also review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and currency, built by political choice among the unequal, necessarily aggravates the imbalances of competitiveness between the center and the periphery.
And it is this that has to be attacked in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rumpelstiltskin, through sanctions and that promote the crushing of wages and incomes with control of one country over another.

Before, through a commitment of the Commissioner, I want countries that have surpluses as well as countries that have deficits, in order to make productivity converge through investment, education, and science.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment and a wave of emigration, which we cannot control.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. The integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, from a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and requires better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the last few years through the various initiatives funded by the reform of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy must, therefore, continue to benefit from adequate financing during the next few years of the current financial programming period.
In this regard, it advocates for adequate financing until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects and support the definition of a stable framework for the objectives of this program.

The issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics that particularly interest some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The regions are regions that, with the exception of French Guiana, being islands and of small size, depend on a reduced number of economic activities and in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume special importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the fact that the European Union has the most extensive exclusive economic zone in the world.
The EU's exclusive economic zone is about 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and together with the coastal regions, it is fundamental for the economic growth of the EU and its member states.
A program like the constant of integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions, privileging the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient financing, not only for the next two years, but also, and above all, for the next financial framework, starting in 2014.
To miss the opportunity when it comes to integrated maritime policy to highlight the enormous potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions enclose for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime frontier of Europe, also establishes its connection to the Americas of the North and South and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe, indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy elaborated with an eye on the future.

And it is thinking about the future that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the articulation of maritime activities, should place in the first line of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension, based on science and technology.

The investigation of the mid-Atlantic ridge, the deep-sea and seabed, constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value for the economy of knowledge.
The Union should take advantage of this, the privileged position of the Azores and the excellence of its oceanographic department to be installed there in the deep sea observatory. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the medicines do not work.
And in the case of the eurozone, the excessive remedies have led it to the brink of death.
The successive miraculous solutions that were being proposed were also equally discredited by the markets.
The financial stabilization fund, the successive reinforcement allotments of the Stability and Growth Pact, the troika's recipes in the countries below the program.
The blind discipline without growth generated a recessionary wave among economies that are completely interconnected, which in turn led to bankruptcies and unemployment.
And in the hands of the markets, that is, of the stock exchanges and speculators, governments are falling behind each other and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is one more step in this disastrous trajectory, with a worsening risk of destroying what remains of national sovereignty, putting countries at the mercy of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to change the treaties.
It is necessary in this emergency that we make two decisions.
First of all, it is necessary to implement a real agenda for sustainable growth and cohesion.
Where is agenda 2020?
Where is the budget for the relaunch?
Where are such projects, the project bonds for the structural investments of Europe?
And secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Naturally, Eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are facing, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a shameful way, but with a definitive position, decided on how it competes with any central bank that defends its currency and the economy it supports.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties, it is necessary political will and European conviction.
We move the treaty when we have learned all the lessons from the present crisis, and there are not a few lessons to learn, but this is surely not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Commissioner Dalli, the first forum of the single market idea that stems from the Greck report took place in Krakow.
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate carried out by the Polish presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12th, with the twelve levers.
It needs to be passed into law, as well as the strategy of the other thirty-eight priorities identified in the act for the single market.
Para que exista mercado é necessário confiança.
