Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be seen as a given acquired, it must be stimulated, nourished.

The single market is not just a buying and selling operation. It involves horizontal policies such as health, social protection and consumer protection, labor law, the environment and sustainable development.
The single market forum should therefore become an emblematic event of the European Union, with an annual event and with a diverse and increasingly participatory public.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I think we are at a turning point in terms of these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social commotion not only in the countries in greater difficulties, in the southern countries, not only in the so-called PIIGS, but also in other contexts in Europe.
Just last week, we had the biggest general strike in Portugal in both the public and private sectors, a strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the biggest strike in history, especially if we take into account that people also took to the streets in Portugal.
We expect on Friday a large demonstration in Brussels.
O que ISTO prova, Senhor Presidente, e o que as greves provam e a saída das pessoas à rua é que as causas e os problemas que nós temos enfrentado são comuns e é por isso que a reação é também comum.
The European Union crisis is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and an increasing inability to secure essential financing for the activities of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that feeds the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budgetary discipline, for profound restructuring, for more economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counter the degradation currently taking place in the Union.

And if it is true that there are precise policies that stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the union will collapse.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of the Treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner, we are all here today, united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are talking about the World AIDS Day and this evaluation of the 2009 resolution and communication is fundamental.
It is fundamental precisely because of things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means that there is much to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and in the European economic area. A 2010 report speaks of more than twenty-five thousand new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than one hundred thousand new cases.
And if we think that there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues that I want to make very clear here has to do with the underinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis that we are currently experiencing.
And this underinvestment has seriously affected areas that are fundamental to the fight against HIV/AIDS.
And that is why, Commissioner, I believe that the Commission has a fundamental role in asking Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also has to do with the increase in discrimination, also evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination of workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment and care should be the same for everyone, regardless of sex, age, or region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are experiencing special and dramatic circumstances, and they require specific and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt has to be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the eurozone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the eurozone, create eurobonds and a European treasury, but all of this takes time.
At this moment we are talking about an emergency and in this context the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, it should not be inhibited in its intervention and action by limited interpretations of its mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this moment, there is no doubt that saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European Neighbourhood Policy already contained in a very explicit way the positions that the European Parliament has been taking on.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House included in the Commission's and the Council's subsequent communications.

I would like to thank, in fact, the excellent and permanent collaboration and coordination that we maintained throughout this time with Vice President Katja Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Fule and their teams.
First of all, for the upgrade achieved in our relationship with our neighboring peoples.

By privileging relations with the population in general and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended exclusively to be based on the universal values that we defend and share.
I would like to point out, however, that the European Union does not intend to impose a model or a predefined formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when what is at stake is the money of our taxpayers, we should give more to those who are doing more in approaching the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and coherent.
What this means, obviously, is that we also anticipate the possibility of having fewer cases or countries in which we will have less.
The neighborhood policy now focuses on defending the prosecution of common values and the commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and good governance.
But this search implies a greater responsibility.
Our partners are called to have more responsibility in the process, so we defend the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality, and the more for more.

By adopting an approach of approximation to our partners from the bottom up and the policies made to measure, what we call the bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies, we make the development and institutional capacity more effective.

Institutional building that we want to defend so much and what is found at the base of the rule of law and the democratic process that we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give the word to the citizens, as well as to all the movements of civil society that identify with our values, giving support to organized movements that strive to obtain positive and democratic changes in their countries.
Countries improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
Etcetera, with fair elections, with the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection, and resource efficiency.
Also the serious economic and social problems that our neighbors face must be the target of immediate action.
It is evident that without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
Were these the ideas that we have always defended for the future European neighbourhood policy?
These are the proposals that are contained in the report that we bring to you for voting.
Now is the time to act.
On our part, we will continue to be attentive and exercise the new powers of monitoring and supervision now conferred upon the European Parliament.

To conclude, I would like to thank my colleague, co-author and friend Marek Siwice, to whom I leave a very special word of thanks for his remarkable work on the eastern side of the neighbourhood policy.
Also to the shadow and opinion reporters and to all of you for the immense suggestions proposed in the amendments that you presented and that I consider have enriched our work.
And a final word for the secretariat of the commission and for the political advisors for the excellent support work that I benefited from.
In European neighborhood policy, without including the outermost regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the peripheral regions convey our values of democracy, peace, respect for human rights and fundamental rights, together with the third countries of these regions.
Regions like the French ultra-peripheral ones have an absolute need for greater integration into their geographical areas.

Distantes do mercado interno da União, essa inserção é fundamental para o seu desenvolvimento e constitui um enorme potencial para o aprofundamento da política de vizinhança com os países terceiros vizinhos.

The neighborhood policy requires a new impetus, an impetus that also takes advantage of the privileged historical and cultural relations that the peripheral regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in promoting the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European neighborhood policy.
Thank you, Mr. President, for the opportunity to speak. I would like to thank the European Commission and the European Parliament for the opportunity to speak.

Retalhistas aos industriais e aos agricultores. O Parlamento aprovou o relatório Bouvier, contendo um exaustivo conjunto de recomendações à Comissão Europeia com o objetivo de um rendimento justo para os agricultores e de um melhor funcionamento da cadeira de abastecimento alimentar.

Since 2008, in fact, communications, reports, recommendations, and high-level forums and groups have been produced in the Commission and Parliament to address this serious problem, without any significant change in practice, despite a greater awareness.

Let's get back to the subject and it is necessary to say it without hesitation, a significant part of the problems that farmers face derive from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, especially by operators of modern distribution.
The problems are more than identified.
What has been missing from the Commission and the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue with the detriment of farmers and consumers.
I want to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is above all dangerous.
First, because it comes to reinforce with more punishments and rigid rules a recipe that does not work.
The recession spiral is launched.
Who can trust a doctor who does not distinguish between anorexia and weight loss?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the remedy while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession for the Commission and the Council to realize that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
Twenty-three million and seven hundred thousand are unemployed.
Almost six million young people have no hope of finding a job.
The Council and the Commission will not realize that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically explosive.
Let's be clear.
The great recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It has to be, however, not of words, but of action.
Onde estão os project bonds para financiar o investimento europeu?
Where is the reinforcement of the European budget with the tax on speculative financial products?
Where is the barrier that was supposed to protect countries from the ruinous interest rates that markets impose on them, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options and not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the governments now promise to reprogram structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is good to remember that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not meet or did not meet the deficit or debt objectives.
It is not necessary to be a genius to understand that either revenge or punishment is due, but the two are not given at the same time.
And it is for this reason, Commissioner, that I would like to ask you a very direct question. Has the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds been maintained, frozen, or annulled?

In other words, Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and other countries may still resort to funds to which they are entitled if they do not meet the objectives that are being imposed by the Commission and by you.
Please answer, Commissioner, is that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you know?
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs.
Stimulate employment, especially young employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are subject to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the external intervention agreement and the great financing difficulties of the economy and, in particular, of our small and medium-sized businesses by the banking system, this proposal assumes special importance for regions such as the Azores, which, with high absorption and good use of funds, are inserted in a recessionary context.

National can here get a real possibility to stimulate their economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our youth generation, more well prepared than ever in the best response to growth and employment that with these funds.
Triumphs, opt.
What we need to know, Commissioner, is how in practice we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

The package of milk that is presented here as an instrument of organization of the sector contains important positive elements, such as the strengthening of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional and contractual aspects that in some Member States may be.

However, quite far from the instruments that the sector needs to prosper in the coming years, in the framework of an agriculture that we want to have in Europe, access to the fair distribution of value in the food chain, which does not turn into an agriculture of large intensive exploitations concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the self-regulation condition in the relationship between actors in the sector is desirable, it is already a grave mistake to think that this alone is sufficient. It can drive away thousands of milk producers, dozens of regions, and even some countries from dairy activity.
The debate on the regulation of the leisure sector from the perspective of a sustainable, economic, social, environmental, and territorial sector continues to be an ongoing process.
And we cannot abandon the quota system without having guaranteed real instruments of supply management.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. From May 2010 to the present, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has become uncontrollable.

It is true that the fight against the crisis, opened by the financial markets, aggravated the indebtedness of the countries of the eurozone and that the most vulnerable became particularly vulnerable.

However, will it be possible for countries sharing the same currency to be subjected to the fate of financial operators' attacks and those who profit from betting on the probability of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Council and Commission's inability to respond have generated problems that are unquestionable today.
Speculative interest rates on individual countries made any exit strategy from the crisis unfeasible.
The consequent aggravation of the country's economic problem justifies a new increase in interest rates until the total cut in credit kills the economy of a country and the contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long been a form of sovereign debt management subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome that finally the Commission has produced a green book on the subject, what was called.

Today, it is clear that without some kind of obligations of this type properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protection barriers, such firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist and, while they do not exist, the euro is in danger and so is Europe.

In the resolution that this parliament approved mainly for the purpose of the new treaty, it was absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing more rules of fiscal stability, budgetary discipline and sanctions on euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the solidarity management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
This is what we expect from the Commission and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this house of European democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the massacre of its own people, which we impotently witness on a daily basis.
Because it is important that Europe can speak with one voice about the meaning of the values of respect for human life in the face of an indiscriminate and ignobly orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the application of new restrictive measures.
The murders have to stop and this is not negotiable.
Insistir no diálogo, sem dúvida.

A democratic Syria needs a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the application of more restrictive measures to the Syrian regime does not exclude the fact that all countries do not move in the same direction and this is not clear and unfortunately has not happened.
In addition to thousands of deaths, the resolutions, shamefully rejected by the United Nations Security Council.
We continue to disapprove of the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains a rotten, desperate and cornered regime continues to govern a country and we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already behind in the hardening of the action of the European Union and the international community.
We have to give more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must support without reservation the work of the Red Cross in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings with a view to punishing those responsible for the crimes that are being perpetrated against humanity.

And as a form of pressure on the countries that have maintained support for Assad, also prohibit the trade exchanges of the European Union with all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
E começar ontem.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Commissioner, to discuss this important topic.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection and, above all, in a context in which there may be conflicts between two different jurisdictions.

E a proteção de dados é de facto um dos domínios sensíveis e que tanta polémica tem gerado e, no meu entender, deve continuar a gerar, porque nós estamos a falar naquilo que pode ser o choque entre os.

The rights and guarantees to safeguard the rights of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then are surpassed when legislation of other countries overcomes European legislation.
It is sensible for several reasons.
It is sensible because there is a break and there is a doubt in what is a contract that for all effects exists between European citizens and European institutions.
These, when they give up their personal data, give up the understanding that they will be protected by European entities and institutions and that they will not be distributed for other purposes.

And therefore, there is a breach of trust here, and this is a fact that is complicated to manage and, on the other hand, it is also a serious and precarious situation, because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking the trust that is generated.

Between European citizens and European institutions and therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different domains, from health issues to other issues, such as those of companies.

What do the data require? I am specifically referring to the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union. What are we doing when citizens assume that they are giving up their data and, as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to tell you, Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the demonstrations of citizens and citizens.

Queiram salvaguardar a proteção dos seus dados pessoais e se houver manifestações que entendam fazer-se porque as instituições europeias não o cumprem, eu acho que devemos estar ao lado dos cidadãos e não do lado contrário.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is carried out, and that is why this question that we ask you, these questions that we put to you, Madam Commissioner, is so that we can clarify once and for all, because no community is built on the basis of or as a foundation of destruction.

The decrease in the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this regard, Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we ensure that European legislation takes precedence over the legislation of third countries?
Because if it is true that European legislation overlaps with the legislation of the twenty-seven member states of the European Union, and this the citizens abdicate.
In this space of sovereignty, at many times, why is it that we can accept that other countries, such as the United States, later override European legislation and override national legislation?
It is necessary that this be clarified, because it is in fact very sensitive and serious, and it is a matter that we must take into account.

And finally, Madam Commissioner, I would like to ask you to please tell us what the Commission is doing to prevent this from happening again, so that the personal data of all citizens is not compromised.

The companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues are, in fact, data in which people can trust that they are protected from what we protect. And with this, I mean that I do not even share the idea that all the information that is stored should be stored, but this is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious issue and as it is a periclitant matter in terms of citizens' rights, I would like you to give us these clarifications so that we can all be more at ease. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to say that in the next Council we expect a major decision at the economic level for the countries that are under aid, which is closely linked to the issue of structural funds.
It is necessary to make structural funds more flexible.
There are many that are about to be used. Much of it has been used only for large infrastructures.
They have to be aimed at competitiveness, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for the relaunch of the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and others can have is the one that results from these structural funds at this time.
Also left a political note for all the politicians of the Union, those who are in good faith in the European process.
Ao falar sobre estes temas, é preciso respeitar ter muito cuidado com o respeito pelas identidades nacionais e pelos Estados membros, e nem todos os Estados membros.
Políticos, às vezes muitos deles com boa intenção, mas nem todos têm estado à altura desse desafio do respeito estrito pela identidade nacional de cada Estado membro.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I greet the speakers, but I would like to say that enough of the hypocritical speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on the macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to be lifted on why, in the European Union and particularly in the eurozone, some countries grow while others decline.
Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets and this agenda must be reviewed because it is here that much of the insufficient internal growth passes, but concentrated in the domestic market.
Four countries, including Germany, have accumulated surpluses successively year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, twenty, have accumulated deficits as well year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external indebtedness of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process has to be controlled.
Of course, discipline is necessary.
But it is important to ask today, is crushing the most fragile with regressive policies the only possible solution?
Will the fiscal competition of some winners within the internal market continue to be tolerated?

Can the largest European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, being certain for its economy, capture in its favor the largest part of the gains of the internal market?
Will the Commission and the Council be able to continue imposing regressive policies that squeeze the economy of the most fragile?
Openly the possibility of bankruptcy of sovereign states in the eurozone when they know that the ceasefire never left the dossier of intentions.
The Commission and the Council are fully aware of the explosive political and economic risk that this speech brings to Europe.
Yes, it is necessary to radically revise the recipes.
But for that, there must be political will.
While this desire does not exist out of respect for citizens, let's stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it's not true.
E os cidadãos não podem continuar a ser enganados.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
To say that we are experiencing the most serious financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is already a common place.
Emphasize that the unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historical records. It is never too much to demand that the fight against unemployment be a priority.
The unemployment of young people is dramatic in my country, Portugal, more than one in every three young people are looking for a job and have no prospects of getting one.
Our citizens are declining.
It is urgent to restore their confidence.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary conciliation reforms and to put the accounts in order.
But we do not give up austerity without economic growth. It is not a partial solution.
The creation of more and better jobs is the great European mission.
Measures to ensure that young people will not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as reducing the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
A year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a significant tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is to tell them that we have learned the lesson. We must learn to deal with natural disasters and nuclear ones. We have the obligation to avoid them.
But unfortunately, this does not seem to be the truth.
One year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants are still being built.
One year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants are still being planned.
O Japão tem, infelizmente, a memória das tragédias que perduram Hiroshima, Nagasaki e nós, europeus, temos também a memória de uma tragédia que perdura Chernóbil.
Fukushima forces us to reopen a debate that should never have been closed. The debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know that it costs lives. They know that this cost has no price. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is the policy of arrogance.
Also here in Europe we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear and despite this, nothing seems to change.
Today there are three hundred and twenty thousand refugees in Japan. Of these, one hundred thousand will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of the soil or contaminated water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited like other ruins, such as a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. However, like these, Fukushima also represents a civilization and the ruin of Fukushima represents our civilization.
The one who chose to include in their development model a deadly technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has responsible parties.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create movements to say goodbye to nuclear power.
Eles sabem melhor do que ninguém que a energia nuclear segura é uma coisa que não existe. Eles sabem melhor do que ninguém que não há testes de estresse.
Simular aquilo que aconteceu em Fukushima e é por isso que nós sabemos que as políticas energéticas são nacionais, mas no céu.
Madam Matias, as already mentioned, diabetes affects more than thirty million people in Europe.
These are, in fact, numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I understand that it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, even more so since it is the first time that this Parliament addresses this issue.

It is the result of a collective effort and is a work that does not cancel out the work done so far on chronic diseases. On the contrary, it reinforces this ability that we have to intervene together.
We have about 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the main cause of, for example, heart attacks, strokes, amputations, failure of vital organs.
And in the face of this data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it is not so serious that we can live well with this and that each government has to deal with it.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that on this side we have a lot to do.
And we have a lot to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution has the value of a beginning and of a joint work in this regard. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I wanted to draw your attention to was to congratulate you on the results of the Council.
Not because the measures are the ideal ones, but because they are the possible ones.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and we can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have made a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states by induction of the European Union.
It is essential for them to regain their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to grow in the long term.
With these guarantees that the states have given, among which the Portuguese state stands out in the sense of consolidating fiscal and budgetary consolidation.
I am convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the twenty-five, that we will be able to seriously relaunch growth in the coming years of the European Council.
But only with this trust that is being generated little by little is this growth to be achieved.
And that is why I say solidarity of the rich with the poor is important, but also the solidarity of the poor with the rich, by providing these guarantees.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to say that it is with great joy that we see that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, Spain, or Greece, which were countries that experienced dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
E por isso a Sérvia merece também esta oportunidade.
I would like, in any case, to give here a note a little different from the one that has been given by my colleagues.

I know and I greet with great concern the concerns of minorities, but it is necessary not to forget the Serbian majority. It is essential that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a place of full rights.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia, and therefore, as much as we emphasize the rights of minorities, they must be respected. We cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity and its full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their state and their national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted last week the Treaty, or rather the final budget, which is not, by the way, a European treaty.

The favorable vote of the government parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of a good student, a grasseyista who does not think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a sweeping vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Assembly of the Portuguese Republic the first parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating one of its most important functions, for which the people elected it, to decide annually the country's budget.
This is another blow from the European Union. Another blow in which the power of money is increasingly beyond the reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that no one can vote anymore? Thank you.
Budget consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, each day there are fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The fiscal burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, consumers, and, meanwhile, there is a complete and disproportionate flight and tax evasion.
The European Socialist Group wanted to know how much this escape and tax evasion were worth in the twenty-seven countries, and they are worth one billion euros, in English, one trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on health.

This means a volume such that if we spent only one-fifth of this value in investment, investment would rise in Europe from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the sense of the resolution that we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear requirement to the Commission and the Council to accelerate the concrete action of combating tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives of fiscal cooperation within the European Union, of fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, in particular Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country bilaterally.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means to reactivate the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
A Europa não é um parceiro menor.
Europe is a great partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation to clearly defend a common fight against fraud and tax evasion in the field of the G20.

Without this, we lose credibility among our citizens and therefore, my final words in this debate are that the Commission and the Council initiate an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to congratulate colleague Niebler for her excellent work and point out the coincidence that on the day of Europe that we celebrate today, we will debate and approve measures that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.
What is at stake in this regulation is imposing limits on the mobile phone rates charged to European consumers when roaming, with the main objective of ending roaming in the European space from 2016.
Our citizens benefit from a sharp decline in prices in relation to calls to SMS and data.

If nowadays there are operators that charge three euros per megabyte from July, the maximum price they can charge is seventy cents per megabyte, increasing this value to twenty cents in two thousand and fourteen.
Regarding the calls received, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in two thousand and fourteen.
In July of two thousand and twelve, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the commissioner said, two hundred euros on their bill.
Second benefit, greater quality of information to consumers.
Already from the summer, the operators are obliged to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only for within the European space.
Third advantage, possibility of entry of more operators in the market, which means an increase in competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able to, if understood in this way, have two contracts, one for services in the national territory and another for services abroad, while maintaining the same number of mobile phones and having only one bill.
Will be equally granted to the consumer, to our citizen, the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of the citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and establishment. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. In February 2009, this Parliament approved a report that supported the European Commission's proposal to revitalize the European economy.
There were clean energy projects, transport, new technologies, innovation, and at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was equated.
After more than three years, we have been able to produce the six pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the budget pact, the two pack, all of them full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.
However, while youth unemployment is reaching alarming levels, the European economy is entering a recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
And meanwhile, and while Greece is no more than a first stone that threatens to make the castle fall, the agenda for relaunch seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is not to attribute an urgent character, but an emergency character in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is necessary to urgently intervene in a set of pillars.
First of all, it is necessary that the European Marshall Plan be constituted with investment, growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates with which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate sovereign debt emissions and jointly manage the debt that is accumulated.
Third point, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank have to prepare to function as real firebreaks in the defense of the European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was generously transferred by the European Central Bank to the commercial bank must reach the companies.
It is a billion euros that is retained in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point, investment does not make sense without research.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that have to free up domestic demand.

It is that almost eighty percent of exchanges take place today within Europe, and it is up to the Commission, Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations aimed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I would like to conclude by saying that we must set a limit to the revenues collected by tolls.

To say enough to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioners, what I wanted to say is very clear, of course, that the Portuguese deputies of the PPE support wholeheartedly all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of.

If we are to get out of this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis, but sometimes when I hear some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think that growth can continue with excessive deficits and with more public accounts.

Now we have to continue to insist on the reduction of spending and structural reforms. We can do everything for the side of growth, but we cannot abandon the path of public spending containment and reduction.

Of the structural reforms, more growth cannot be more relaxed, more rest, more growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and with great rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and think that there are magic solutions for growth, we will end up again in an unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

Having said that, I would like to draw attention to the fact that at the summit tomorrow, it will not only be the long-term or medium-term growth issue that will be at stake, but also the urgent issue of Greece. And I believe it is essential for the European states to somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem and I would like to repudiate here the statement of the British MP who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe, perhaps.
A europeização da europa pelo menos no plano dos valores não fosse uma coisa negativa e portanto rejeito esta ideia de tentar enfim humilhar ou tentar reduzir quaisquer povos.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I have come here to tell us that every additional euro spent on debt is one euro less for job creation. So, please explain to us why we should continue with this obsession.

I also want to tell you that one of the priorities of the summit is to keep Greece in the eurozone. And I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe in ourselves or do we believe in Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who said the exact opposite a few days ago?
You spoke about the maintenance of the eurozone. I ask, in which euro?

In the euro that we currently live in this area that we currently live in or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study in which it referred to a G euro, a second-class euro, in case the left won the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, the trap of a Europe hostage to governments and the trap of a Europe hostage to financial interests.
Let's not let people live in fear, because it is not a way of living. Europe can be something else. The wise man, there is no lack of money, there is no lack of shame.

Mr President, Mr Vaman, the first thing I would like to say is that it is regrettable that in a debate of this importance, the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative, Mrs Ashton, are not present.
In any case, we have the pleasure of working once again with Mr. Minister Vaiman, who here made a statement in which I fully agree.

I would like to first give a word of comfort and solidarity to the people of Guinea, who have basically been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability and great insecurity.
It is no longer enough to be surrounded by poverty. It has been systematically affected by these evils.

I would like to say, on the other hand, that the PPE, in its presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning and that it is also regrettable that the European Parliament, only at the end of a month, can have a debate on this matter.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is due to the fact that, unlike other very serious matters, there are no large-scale economic interests at stake here that motivate the European, American, and global powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
Mas eu devo dizer se é preciso um motivo externo, se não basta a miséria e instabilidade política para nós termos uma ação humanitária e política global.
At least the situation of drug trafficking that plagues Guinea and that directly affects European peoples and American peoples should be a reason for us to engage in this.
And for that reason, I ask the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that the resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-speaking countries, the African Union, but perhaps not the Community of States of West Africa, are going in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, actions are needed.
We have to be firmer, we have to be more effective together with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea Bissau.
This is our obligation.

I believe that the European Union is currently responding well in terms of principles, but it will be responding as it should in terms of practical instruments for on-the-ground operation. And that is what I ask of the Council and the Commission.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Globalization has brought with it an out-of-proportion growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as is known, seventy times greater than global wealth.

The opacity, the very frequent transactions, the high remuneration, the very high risk ended up not only characterizing the world in which we live today, but also being fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis has come to demand accountability and effort much more from ordinary citizens than from the sector that caused it.
So today this moment is important.

It is important and I would personally like to obtain a situation in which the tax is generalized in all countries of the European Union and subsequently extended to the rest of the world through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be comprehensive or to cover all products without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the Union's own resources.
In the short term, we must accept commitments, but we must not lose sight of where we need to go.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission and with a great spirit of commitment on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only thank the role not only of Annie Pali-mata, who was tireless in this process, as well as all those who managed to overcome differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today we are discussing for the first time the tax on financial transactions, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go completely unpunished in this crisis we are living through.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people, not to the financial markets.
For decades, the lobbies of the financial markets have been able to govern the world without opposition and without any problem.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the speculative financial market crisis was at the root of most of the problems we are experiencing.
And yet, these speculative financial markets not only prevented anything from being done, but also facilitated a direct transfer of citizens' funds to these same speculative markets.

For many years, we have been fighting for this, Mr. President, but it was only when the peoples of all over Europe began to say enough that there was finally some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
And therefore, this is the answer we have to give to the citizens. It is a first signal that we have to give them.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything paid, do not deserve to be disrespected.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have not walked, the European leaders have walked to apologize to the financial markets.
Deviam pedir desculpas às pessoas que têm afetado.
And to conclude, Mr. President, a politician who is now famous, we are talking about these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of confidence to people and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of my colleagues, we begin to talk about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, muster courage, let's get this project through.
Thank you, Mr. President. The tax on financial transactions should function as a means of controlling and discouraging high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and expand healthy competition based on the single market and also generate revenue.

The Podi mata report tried to bring the initial proposal of the European Commission closer to the well-known stamp tax of the United Kingdom. Thus, we make this proposal more attractive to reluctant member states.
It is expected that the council will also understand the message.

Thank you very much, Madam President. In addition to my thanks to all those who collaborated to achieve this result, I would like to ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately with the Troika.

Countries with deficits also have to affect countries that have surpluses and if some have to crush their internal demand, others have to free it.

Parliament the need to immediately launch an instrument for growth and for anti-cyclical activity of the order of one percent of the GDP of the European Union for ten years.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. It is true that it has been six months since this scandal with the IPP, and the most incredible thing is that for ten years, a private company could have achieved.
To operate in the market and have introduced silicone implants that should be intended for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in seventy-one countries.
This affected a large number of thousands of women, as already mentioned, it is estimated that around five hundred thousand.

Now we are talking about estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, a fraud, a court case, but we also know.

There is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts, and the courts will deal with it, but there is a legal loophole, a legal void, and we must deal with it. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For ten years, we were unable to identify what the criminals had identified, and therefore there was a vacuum in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of archives, in terms of records, everything failed. But these gentlemen of this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control, and that is why.

In this process, there is not only the issue of lack of information, which is very important, in fact, the lack of information in all issues related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to find out if they had placed or not implants correctly.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax in public health matters. We control so many unnecessary things, we even control the authenticity of spare parts in cars. We recently approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The review of the directive on medical devices is good news. It was the best news that we didn't have to do it, but now that we are going to do it, we apply it with.

Conditions with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately, the sanctions, even when applied, will not be applied to the women who suffered from this problem and the states must assume full responsibility.

Thank you, Mr. President, because I wanted to affirm very clearly that for us it is fundamental the Council that will take place at the end of June and that what is essential is that a European solution is sought for this crisis.

Thank you, Mr. President. In fact, the election of the president, the new Egyptian president in the post-Mubarak era, is good news, but we cannot delude ourselves. These presidential elections do not in any way close the process of transition that is taking place in Egypt.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, the future common fisheries policy must prioritize the environmental, economic, and social sectors.
In a synergistic and non-hierarchical way, in favor of sustainable development and in accordance with the objectives of the smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth strategy of the year 2020.
As relator of the REGI opinion, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the Azores, whose economies are strongly dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should aim to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thus safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that must take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in the various coastal regions.

I defend that this policy places the focus on regionalization as a form of governance, through a reinforcement of the participation of the various interested parties, so that it is possible in the future, a more adequate response to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are reaching decisive moments in which we will shape the new fishing policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency of achieving sustainable balances in our fisheries, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and in the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the provision of quality food, require, as never before, courage and bold measures.
We therefore have to make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, proposing that the exploration of its resources be done taking into account scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in its exploration and restricting external access beyond one hundred miles to the existing fishing banks.
To preserve the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

I propose that our communities have better management of their fishing affairs with the creation of a regional consultative council, more suitable for the peripheral regions. I hope that we can have a better future in this way.

The banking union and banking supervision, because it remains to be clarified and resolved an essential issue that is the role of the Parliament, the only institution democratically elected by the citizens directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern and has to do with the following: the instruments of monetary policy are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

The banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union, and, however, if everything goes wrong, if the banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying this bankruptcy remains with the taxpayers of the national states. It remains a national responsibility.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline. And I ask, budgetary discipline, so let's go to it, because what exactly do we say when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the commitments of the state in the middle. In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

Budgetary discipline is respecting commitments in health, education, culture, and not closing services or ending and canceling projects halfway. Discipline is putting banks in order and not walking and pulling taxpayers to put in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary discipline that I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue with this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget that is being discussed in Portugal, at the behest of Troika, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any state should have with its citizens, in order not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors, which are bringing Europe and its countries together.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate myself on the results of the Council, although it seems to me that the final decision is a little delayed.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I see myself in everything that my colleague Kaxu Lides said, I would like to ask the President of the Council a question: which countries are under assistance?
Countries that are in difficulties have fought hard to have a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But we heard yesterday statements from the highest German and French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special situation.
What I am asking is whether the Council has approved any discriminatory treatment decision for Ireland, unlike the one reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Dear colleagues, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the twenty concerns of citizens and companies.
Regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, in which the 20th anniversary of this market is being marked.
A first word to thank the colleagues of all political groups and, in particular, the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, for their constructive contributions and positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report benefited greatly from our joint effort.

We know well and are proud that, over these twenty years, the single market has been the engine of great economic and employment opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European companies.
Travel, reside and work in the space of the Union are freedoms that are within the reach of all citizens of the twenty seven Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities with access to five hundred million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis in
In 2008, it is enough to pay attention to the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the 2.13% additional growth of GDP.
Today, making a phone call or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is cheaper, thirteen percent, than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people has its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
More than two and a half million students have benefited from this European exchange program for education and mobility.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative costs due to the single market legislation.
But a question arises, is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative effects on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens in some countries, living with the drama of unemployment and being confronted with austerity measures, have come to have a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or do not understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States unjustifiably delay the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thus hindering its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another country of the Union, the opening of a bank account by a student of the program.

Erasmus, the change of energy supplier, the transfer of pension reform, the recognition of qualifications, and the registration of a vehicle in another member state are still very complex, difficult, or onerous acts.
It is important to address these issues.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message written in the report is very clear. We need more political will, much more political will from the Member States and the European institutions.

Council, especially the Council and Commission, to govern better and together, it is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I take this opportunity to greet the European Commission on behalf of Commissioner Barnier for the presentation of the Action Plan for the Market 2012, twelve priority actions for a new growth that marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier and dear colleague Regina Bastos, I congratulate you on your efforts that have already borne fruit.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the single market was created in 1992.
De Gaulle synthesized then the three basic principles of the single market, competition that stimulates, cooperation that reinforces, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years ago, the economic and financial crisis revived the threat of national protectionism and made it clear that the internal market is not a completed work.

And the celebration of these twenty years has to be taken advantage of to relaunch the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To do this, priorities must be defined, and I would like to speak of a priority in particular.
It is essential a common policy to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices to the consumer with a high level of energy efficiency.
Through the European energy market, served by transborder infrastructures, with the possibility of community leverage of the investment that represents added European value.
Na energia também, senhora presidente, vai-se jogar o mercado comum.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which surely represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its member states, and its regions.
However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize their policies in the sense of equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the ultra-peripheral regions, through their greater insertion into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness, improving their conditions of competition, but we will never be able to do it if we do not solve our accessibility problems in the transport areas better.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the problems caused by our detachment.
We therefore believe that the Commission should consider a specific program, such as the POSI transport, as an essential instrument for the insertion of these types of regions in the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to begin by thanking you for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.
I greet the presence of Minister Mavroyiannis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive attitude, some for a skeptical attitude that is understandable.

And to say thank you very much to Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he puts into the discussion of these issues, of these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We have much to answer to the citizens.
The citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned and expect more from us. They expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the Member States.
This balance sheet is very useful. This balance sheet of twenty years is important, but as many said here, it is important to open the door to the future.
And the look to the future goes through many issues that were raised here and through many measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The single digital market, citizens' mobility, the reform of the European energy portal, and the European energy market are examples.
Eloquent that we still have an important path to make in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this time of crisis that we are experiencing.
The citizens are suffering. The citizens are waiting for the politicians and the answers that the politicians can give to the adverse conditions that they are suffering.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the answers to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are more determined to provide the answers that our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozes report, together with the report that we will prepare on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year and that will precede the Spring Council, are two essential parts of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the Member States by the Council under the proposal of the Commission, and these recommendations frame, as has just been said, with.
The six pack and the future two pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of Member States.

The balance between this control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find, and it has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline, and ultimately, it may even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

On the subject of the two-pack, I would like to briefly comment that it is important that the council, which is absent here today, gives a negotiating mandate to its negotiators, compatible with the ambition of quickly concluding this package, this two-pack.

But more European coordination, returning to the topic, means a lesser control of the countries over their own destiny, which obliges a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to the countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between the medium and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and the short-term recommendations, which are mainly focused on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, it is necessary that there is coherence.

With the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular, on the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities of the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary that we agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labor rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed based on the results achieved, which is far from the case so far.

I would like to thank the spirit of collaboration of Mr. Gozes and hope that he will take one more step in this spirit, in order to expand the basis of consensus around his report and that this spirit will also remain with regard to the next one.
It is true, and as has been mentioned many times here, that there are many things that we do not know about the extraction of shale gas.
Mas há também muitas que já sabemos e convém não esquecê-las.

We know, for example, that each operation of shale gas extraction uses more than nineteen million liters of drinking water, which is enough to supply one thousand European citizens per year in terms of their needs.

We also know that each extraction of shale gas that is made in each of the operations is pumped into the ground. Thirty to three hundred tons. I apologize. Tons can go up to three hundred tons of chemicals and about eighty percent of which remain in the ground and do not come out of there.

We also know that in each extraction of shale gas, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsoil, which, together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a contamination risk of drinking water resources and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that the extraction of shale gas is also a response that is apparently easy, which only thinks about the immediate, the industry and the profit, ignores the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also Europe that knows in this House that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and that must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and health standards.
Therefore, when you don't know everything, being cautious is the minimum.
